(CP) _ A forest fire north of here forced the evacuation of two homes on Tuesday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Bob Beck, fire control officer for the Kamloops Fire Centre, said the 10-hectare blaze began at about 3 p.m. near Clearwater, about 100 kilometres north of Kamloops.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"A couple of houses were within 200 metres of the fire so the residents had to be removed,'' he said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>"So far we haven't heard reports of any damage.''</p><p>About 30 firefighters from the Clearwater fire department and the B.C. Forest Service were battling the blaze with the support of two helicopters, with more equipment on the way. The cause of the fire was unknown.</p><p>Wildfires last summer drove about 10,000 to from their homes in the Kamloops area, while the Okanagan Mountain Blaze in the Kelowna area prompted evacuation notices for 30,000.</p><p>Even as crews battled the new blaze, B.C. Forest Service officials said they were making plans to implement recommendations from a report on the devastating summer fires by former Manitoba premier Gary Filmon.</p><p>The report recommended the province commit to burn off a layer of debris which otherwise might accelerate wildfires.</p><p>Officials are planning to thin trees and build fuel breaks around the outskirts of communities.</p><p>Landowners can help by pruning and thinning trees, said Jim Mottishaw, manager for the Penticton fire zone.</p><p>With the drought index showing the lack of moisture in forests at mid-June levels, everyone should prune their trees and clear forest waste from their properties, forest officials cautioned.</p><p>"Unless we see spring rains, we'll be into a dry season with greater fire risk,'' said Mottishaw. "It means more stubborn fires and fires that burn deeper, hotter and farther.''</p><p>Federal Environment Minister David Anderson also announced Tuesday the local regional district will receive more than $470,000 in federal funds to pay young people to clean up forest fuels in district parks.</p><p>(Kelowna Daily Courier, Kamloops Daily News)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier PARRY SOUND -UPDATE (Monday, Aug. 20, 2 p.m.) On the afternoon of Aug. 20, there are 37 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, four fires are not yet under control. The remaining 33 fires are either being held, under control or being observed. There were two new fires confirmed today, at the time of this update, both near Sault Ste. Marie.

One Incident Management Team is in place in the region. It is managing Parry Sound 33, which is being held at 11,362 hectares. To find an updated map of current travel restrictions visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

Although the fire perimeter remains restricted, waterway and road restrictions were lifted effective 6 p.m. on Aug. 15. However, the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services advises the fire perimeter will remain restricted for quite some time. There is still a Notice to Airmen in place over the fire for aircraft.

Ground crews continue to extinguish hot spots within the fire perimeter and will continue moving to priority areas to search for additional hot spots.

Local residents will continue to see smoke drift from this fire over the next two or three days as weather conditions remain hot and dry.

Restricted Fire Zone in effect

A restricted fire zone remains in effect in areas north of Rosseau, northwest to Espanola and Cartier, over to the Quebec border including Temagami and Mattawa north of the Mattawa River. This includes Parry Sound, Burk's Falls, Powassan, North Bay and Greater Sudbury. For a visual representation of the affected areas please visit our interactive map Ontario.ca/forestfire.

Travel restrictions

In order to ensure MNRF and emergency officials are able to continue fire suppression operations in areas affected by large forest fires, travel restrictions remain in place near the Parry Sound 33, North Bay 72 and Pembroke 6 forest fires. These restrictions are in place to ensure public safety and the safety of emergency personnel working in the affected areas. Although some restrictions have been removed, others remain in place. For information on travel restrictions and travel permits, please call 1-888-220-7242. For a visual representation of the affected areas please visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

RESTRICTED FIRE ZONES

Due to the extreme fire hazard, recent heavy lightning, little precipitation and increased forest fire, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry implemented Restricted Fire Zones across a major part of the northeast and central region as outlined on the interactive fire map. This will remain in place until further notice. See the fire map for the zones covered.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ontario Ministry of Resources and Forestry expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS

For details on travel restrictions in the Parry Sound and Sudbury districts visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, 2018, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of Parry Sound District where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity from Parry Sound 33.

The order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions. This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

Waterways - All travel and use of the Pickerel River west of Hwy 69 to Bear Island and Key River west of Hwy 69 to Georgian Bay including all access from Georgian Bay on those water ways entering the fire perimeter or adjacent to it on its northern boundary, is prohibited during the daylight hours of 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. unless authorized by travel permit issued by Parry Sound District or Sudbury District Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

Roadways - All road access west of Hwy 69 south of Pickerel River in Mowat Township and the unsurveyed lands to the southern border of Henvey Inlet 2 Indian Reserve is prohibited unless authorized by travel permit issued by Parry Sound District or Sudbury District Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

Fire Perimeter - There is no access permitted within the fire perimeter as shown on the map unless authorized by travel permit issued by Parry Sound District or Sudbury District Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF).

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for nonrecreational purposes, please call to 705-746-4201 to request a travel authorization permit. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

SMOKE CONCERNS

Smoke from large fires across the region will be visible until fire activity is reduced and weather patterns change.

Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services is reminding the public that if they do see flames or smoke, please report it, and stay away from the area in the interest of public safety.

If you have questions or concerns about smoke and your health, please contact Tele Health Ontario at 1-866-797-0000.

Aggressive fire suppression operations are ongoing throughout the entire fire area. There are 247 firefighters and support staff currently working on this incident.

On the morning of Aug. 9, there are 49 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 17 are not yet under control, 32 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There were nine new fires confirmed yesterday (Wednesday, Aug. 8), two of which had already been extinguished, as of 8 a.m. on Thursday, Aug. 9. Parry Sound 41 was not yet under control at 0.4 of a hectare, located just east of Parry Sound 33, at 8 a.m. on Thursday, Aug. 9. It started at approximately 4:33 p.m. on Wednesday, Aug. 8 and was listed as human-caused. The fire is no longer shown on the map.

So far in 2018, there have been 971 forest fires inside Ontario's fire region, according to the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. That compares to 354 fires in 2017 and a 10-year average of 567 forest fires per year.

UPDATE (Tuesday, Aug. 7, 9:40 p.m.): Though not yet under control, according to the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, Parry Sound 33 had no new growth Tuesday, August 7. The fire is holding at 11,362 hectares.

Crews continue to work the perimeter and containment around the fire is almost complete. The total perimeter is almost 120 kilometers long. There are 275 firefighters and support staff currently working on this incident. That number will continue to fluctuate as staff complete their 14 day assignment and more staff become available after days of rest.

By the evening of August 7, there were 43 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 14 are not yet under control, 29 are either being held, under control or being observed.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Tuesday, Aug. 7, 9:40 p.m.): Though not yet under control, according to the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, Parry Sound 33 had no new growth Tuesday, August 7. The fire is holding at 11,362 hectares.

Although this fire received approximately 10 millimetres of rain, extremely dry fuel conditions remain.

Firefighters took advantage of the precipitation, high humidity and low winds to continue consolidating hose lines around the perimeter. Crews continued to move inward to solidify control lines.

By the evening of Aug. 6, there were 44 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 18 are not yet under control, 26 are either being held, under control or being observed. There were four new fires confirmed on Monday, Aug. 6, two of which are already been called out, including Parry Sound 38, which was located south of Parry Sound 33. It was confirmed at 0.1 hectares and declared out on Monday, Aug. 6.

UPDATE (Sunday, Aug. 5, 10:55 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown once again, to 11,362 hectares and is still not yet under control.

The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry say it was a challenging, hot and windy day on Aug. 5 and the fire responded as they expected.

However, even with the challenges and high temperatures, the crews managed to maintain the perimeter of the fire, thanks to the placement of the hose lines. Two minor spot fires on the northeast flank were quickly contained in the morning of Aug. 5.

Crews have made excellent progress over the last few days and now have hose lines around most of the fire perimeter. More work still needs to be done as crews will work inward to solidify the control lines.

Some structure protection (sprinklers) will be removed in areas of the fire where full containment has been achieved and the threat from those structures has been removed.

Some precipitation was reported over the fire on Aug. 5 and the MNRF is hopeful that the interior of the fire receives more rain from the weather system.

Today (Aug. 6), once again, there is the potential for strong winds. Some unsettled weather may bring some scattered thunderstorms with the possibility of 10 to 15 millimetres of patchy rain. It is anticipated that temperatures will be in the mid to high 20s with high humidity. Winds could august up to 30 kilometres an hour or more.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (Saturday, Aug 4, 11:23 p.m.)

No new fires reported.

News coming from the MNRF for the Northeast region on Aug 4 is positive.

By the evening of August 4, there were 44 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 19 are not yet under control, 25 are either being held, under control or being observed.

Nine forest fires are still active to the south and west of Fort Severn in the Far North. FireRanger crews and Coastal Rangers are responding.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (Friday, Aug. 3 11:39 p.m.)

"The fire is suppressed nicely along the Key River."

This good news is coming from the most recent MNRF Northeast Region Forest Fire Situation Update.

However the fire is still more than 11,000 hectares - a single hectare is about the size of an international soccer pitch. So imaging 11,000 soccer pitches. The evacuees from Henvey are expected to be out of their homes for another week.

On Friday higher humidity helped firefighers work on the blaze, laying hose around the perimeter of the fire.

"Bucketing helicopters assisted crews in keeping the spread of the fire in check," states the MNRF release.

Read the rest of the MNRF release here:

"Helicopter bucketing helped suppress isolated pockets of higher intensity, including torching, within the perimeter of the fire.

The west side of the fire remained quiet. Crews started to work into the interior of the perimeter along the south end of Key Harbour.

Tomorrow's weather calls for higher temperatures with low humidity. The hot, dry weather, coupled with the forecasted southwesterly winds, may cause an increase in fire behaviour and test our fire lines. If such an event occurs, we have the resources to respond appropriately.

It is important to note that while good progress is being made, the fire remains active. The conditions continue to be very dry, and extreme burning conditions are still possible. Land and water restrictions remain in place at this time for protection of people, property and to allow our crews to do their work. Patrols from OPP and Conservation Officers will continue throughout the area around the fire.

We continue to work hard to manage Parry Sound 33 in order to get people back into their residences safely. We thank you for your patience and ongoing support.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Thursday, August 2, 11:40 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown to 11,185 hectares in size, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

The ministry reports that Thursday, August 2, was another great day for crews working and laying hose around the perimeter of the fire. Crews continue to make excellent progress in critical areas, especially along the northeast side of the fire near the Pickerel River. Higher winds out of the southwest today tested the northeast perimeter, but the hose lines held and kept the fire's spread in check. It is estimated that most of the east flank has been tied with hose line.

On Thursday, August 2, waterbombers and helicopters worked in conjunction with the crews to help tie off areas of activity. The fire remains south of Key Harbour, and north of the Henvey Inlet waterway. Crews are working on perimeter containment on the southeast side of the fire north of Henvey Inlet.

The west side of the fire remains unchanged; the fire remained quiet in the vicinity of Fox Island on the western perimeter. Crews continue suppression along the western flank of the fire. Structural protection continues.

Even with Thursday's winds, the fire remains approximately five kilometers away from Highway 69 and less than one kilometer south of the Pickerel River near the CN trestle bridge on the west side of Highway 69. Today's weather calls for another day of southwesterly winds.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Wednesday, August 1, 11:55 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown to 11,039 hectares in size, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

The ministry reports recent weather allowed more accurate aerial mapping of the fire and aerial ignition in the southeast added to the increased size. Fire behaviour was less active yesterday, August 1, as high humidity levels and cloud cover aided in fire suppression. Winds were generally out of the east today and changed the fire's direction of spread to the west. Hose lines on the west side of the fire held the fire's spread in check.

The ministry reports that excellent progress was made on the eastern side of the fire as crews were able to establish lines due to reduced fire behaviour when compared to previous days. Crews are laying hose from the Pickerel River south to establish a perimeter on areas that have passed over the CN line. Structural protection continues along the Key and French Rivers.

Crews continue to work the perimeter of the fire by the north and northwest of Key Harbour. Sixty firefighters remain along the east side, south of the Key River to continue perimeter containment. Aerial ignition occurred in the southeast part of the fire removing hazardous fuels and tying the fire into the northern shore of Henvey Inlet.

Even though the focus of aerial fire suppression is on the northeast side, crews continue to supress and monitor all portions of the fire. The fire remained quiet in the vicinity of Fox Island on the western perimeter. North and east winds yesterday, August 1, made for smoky conditions in communities to the south. Winds are forecasted to be out of the south today, August 2, moving to the southwest in the afternoon. The fire is approximately five kilometres west of highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of Pickerel River near the CN trestle bridge on the west side of highway 69.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Tuesday, July 31, 10:45 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown to 10,139 hectares in size, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

On Tuesday, July 31, fire behaviour was less active as humidity levels and cloud cover aided in fire suppression. The northeast portion of the fire closest to the Pickerel River was the most active part today. Winds from the southwest pushed some activity along the Pickerel, but it's still holding south of the river. The northeast corner of the fire is tucked along the west side of Little Canoe Channel. Ignition operations in that area were completed Tuesday evening, July 31, to tie the fire together and slow its progression down.

Structural protection continues. Additional protection occurred along the Key and French Rivers with sprinklers set up in noted priority zones. Crews worked the perimeter of the fire by continuing hose line north and northwest of Key Harbour. Sixty firefighters were placed along the east side, south of the Key River to continue perimeter containment. Even though the focus is on the northeast side, the ministry continues to supress and monitor all portions of the fire.

Winds are forecasted to be out of the north today, Aug, 1. The fire is approximately five kilometres west of Highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of Pickerel River.

The Municipality of Killarney issued an evacuation order for residents in the areas of Travers, Allen, Struthers, Kilpatrick, Bigwood (including Hartley Bay Road), a portion of Mowat, the Unsurveyed Area, 14 Mile Island and French River Provincial Park. For information, call the municipality at 705-287-2424.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Monday, July 30, 11:52 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire reportedly expanded by 749 hectares on Monday, reaching 8,973 hectares, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services. The fire is now approximately five kilometres west of Highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of the Pickerel River.

On Monday, July 30, winds occurred from the west/southwest. The northeast and east portions of the fire were the most active and a few of these sections progressed eastward towards the CN Line. Crews have been working hard to slow the fire's progression in this part of the fire.

Structural protection continues, with sprinklers set up on structures along the Pickerel and Key Rivers, as well as on structures along the French River on Hartley Bay Road.

Crews worked on the southeast portion to hold the perimeter and complete hose line, while water bucketing and water bombers along the east flank continued aerial suppression efforts to attempt to close in the fire.

The ministry reported that although the focus is currently on the northeast side, they continue to suppress and monitor all portions of the fire. Aerial ignition on portions of the fire near Fox Island have brought the fire to natural boundaries removing the fire hazard in this area.

The fire behaviour today, Tuesday, July 31, is expected to remain the same as Monday. High temperatures mixed with low humidity will be present on the fire site. Winds from the west/southwest will occur again into today, possibly bringing more smoke into surrounding communities and along Highway 69.

An Evacuation Alert has been issued by the Municipality of French River for the Alban area, west of the high-powered hydro lines on Highway 64. For more information on the evacuation, call the municipality at 705-898-2294 or visit frenchriver.ca.

The ministry reports northern areas of the fire held up well Sunday, July 29, west of Key Junction; however, parts of the northeast flanks south of Key Junction were quite active, but haven't yet crossed the rail line.

Structural protection was completed in Henvey Inlet. Protection for Key River and Grundy Lake will begin today. Equipment will be removed from Key Harbour as perimeter control has been completed in that area.

Aerial suppression continued yesterday with water bomber and water bucketing efforts on the east flank of the fire. Winds from the west and southwest are expected to continue today, Monday, July 30, possibly bringing more smoke into surrounding communities and along Highway 69. The fire remains six kilometres west of Highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of the Pickerel River near the CN trestle bridge on the west side of Highway 69.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (8:26 a.m. Sunday, July 29) - Parry Sound 33 had minimal growth yesterday increasing in size from 7,297 to 7,651.

In a news release sent out by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry shortly before midnight on Saturday, July 28, the fire is still listed as not under control.

Water bombers and helicopters worked most of the day on July 28, limiting movement among most areas of the fire's perimeter with generally good results.

The southwest winds are expected to continue today, possibly bringing heavy smoke conditions periodically into surrounding communities along Highway 69. The fire remains approximately seven kilometres west of Highway 69 and three kilometres south of the Pickerel River and is nearly 100 kilometres north of Parry Sound.

For most of Saturday, July 28, winds from the southwest continued, keeping the northeast side as the most active part of the fire. Priority remains along the northeast side of the fire with fingers extending toward the CN rail line as minimal movement occurred across the tracks. Additionally, there was minimal growth along the southwest portion of the fire.

Hose lay and containment will continue along the northern portion as crews look to secure that area.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (8:20 a.m. Saturday, July 28) - Parry Sound 33 is still not under control and continues to grow.

In a news release sent out at 12:35 a.m. on July 28, the fire has grown to 7,297 hectares. Due to the southwest winds, the northeast side is the most active part of the fire.

The northeast side of the fire is the focus for Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry water bombers and helicopter bucketing, as it is closest to the rail line and more populated areas.

There has been minimal growth on the southwest end of the fire.

Southwest winds are expected to continue tomorrow, possibly bringing heavy smoke conditions periodically into surrounding commentates and along Highway 69. The fire is approximately seven kilometres west of Highway 69 and three kilometres south of the Pickerel River.

Wildfire crews continue to make progress around the southwest side of the perimeter by laying hose lines and actively attacking hot spots in the Key Harbour. That area is protected and the MNRF does not expect any movement in that area over the next few days.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 p.m. Thursday, July 26): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports Parry Sound 33 is still not under control and growing.

According to the ministry in a news release dated 11:55 p.m., Thursday, July 26, by the evening of July 26 there were 45 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held, under control or being observed. Of the 15 not under control, Parry Sound 33 is one of them.

As of July 26, the fire is estimated at 6,760 hectares and there was minimal grown on the north, west and south end of the fire. The implementation order and all access restriction, including water access restriction, remain in place. The southwest winds are expected to continue today, possibly gusting from 30 to 40 kilometres per hour. Unfortunately, there is minimal precipitation in the forecast.

"Crews continue to make excellent progress around the southwest side of the perimeter, laying hose and working on hotspots north and south of Key River," reads the release."Today's focus was on the north and east flank of the fire, which were once again active due to sustained southern and southwesterly winds. The fire did put on some growth along the east flank, with one area of the fire crossing both Tower Lake and impacting the CN rail in one location."

Continued growth of the fire is expected on the northeast flank today. Water bombers and helicopters worked most of the day halting or slowing the spread of the fire. Values protection, or sprinklers, continue to be placed along Pickerel River and began in Henvey Inlet as a precautionary measure.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 a.m. Wednesday, July 25): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Fire has expanded Northeast region restricted fire zone.

Due to strong, warmer and drier lake effect winds the ministry required aerial fire suppression yesterday, July 25, as fire activity increased. As a result of the the southwest winds, smoke was pushed across Highway 69 and into some communities to the east of the fire.

Resources yesterday included CL415 water bombers, two bird dog aircraft, heavy helicopters T802 amphibious aircraft and ground crews, the ministry reports.

Additional crews from Mexico arrived on the fire today, bringing the total number of firefighters helping to suppress the fire to 90. Values protection, or sprinklers, will continue to be put in place on structures along the Pickerel River today.

"Given the unpredictability of the fire, all access restrictions, including water restrictions, remain in place for the foreseeable future," reads a ministry press release. "In the interest of public safety, on July 21, 2018 the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF)'s Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area below impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only: All areas ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay."

There is also a recommendation by the ministry Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

By the evening of July 25 there were 50 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 16 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There were two new fires confirmed in the region today. Hearst 14, located approximately 42 kilometres south of Hearst, is two hectares and not yet under control. Two crews provided initial attack on the fire with aerial suppression support. Wawa 11 is being held at 0.1 hectares 75 kilometres southeast of Longlac.

(Tuesday, July 24, 11:10 p.m.):The fire is expected to remain relatively quiet for the next couple of days.

"However, fire conditions and behaviour can change quickly. Crews continue to monitor weather and fire behaviour closely. Residents will see smoke in the area as crews continue suppression efforts. Values protection have been put in place in Key Harbour, along parts of the south side of Pickerel River and along a portion of the train tracks east of the fire."

A total of eight helicopters worked the fire on July 24.

As of July 24 the fire was at 5,612 hectares and still not under control.

The cause of the fire was originally stated as "human" on the MNR's website but that classification has since been removed, McCool said, to avoid public speculation.

"Because the cause is still unknown at this time and it is under investigation."

(11:59 p.m., Monday, July 23): The Key River forest fire, known as Parry Sound 33, is now covering an area of 5,612 hectares and the restricted fire zone has been expanded to north of Rosseau.

According to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services, Parry Sound 33 saw aerial fire suppression again on Monday, July 23. CL415s dropped water on the fire which was remapped at 5,612 hectares. Three heavy helicopters bucketed water to reduce the fire's intensity and co-ordinated with ground crews.

On July 21, the MNRF's Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only.

There is also a recommendation by the MNRF Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

In addition, the MNRF's Sudbury district has recommended that all residents along Hartley Bay Road be placed on an evacuation alert, pending changes to the fire situation.

The Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) and Conservation Officers have been on site helping notify the public of the situation, and facilitating this evacuation.

Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services (AFFES) has also been advised by Ontario Parks that the French River Provincial Park is fully closed west of Highway 69/400. All campers have been or are being evacuated. Ontario Parks has also suspended permit sales for the French River Delta and Pickerel River areas and are restricting entry to park users (everything west of Highway 69/400).

Henvey Inlet First Nation declared a state of emergency as a precautionary measure. As of July 22, the community has successfully and safely evacuated all of its community members, who are receiving accommodation and food.

By the evening of July 23 there were 55 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 21 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There was only one new start in the region today. Sudbury 92 located near Johnnie Lake in Killarney Provincial Park covers 0.1 of a hectare and is already under control.

urn:contentItem:4713-YK10-01G6-84VM-00000-00<published>1993-07-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Prairies-Forest-Fire, Bgt</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>By Penny Caster</p><p nitf:lede="true">= The Canadian Press</p><p nitf:lede="true">= The uneasy exile of the population of Lynn Lake, Man., evacuated midweek as a huge forest fire crackled just beyond town, is expected to last at least till next Tuesday. That's the earliest Manitoba Hydro predicted power would be flowing to the community again, said a spokesman for the province's Emergency Measures Organization. Brian Kozak said the fire is contained and showers are helping the 150 firefighters working to get the best of it. It covers 18,000 hectares, about one-third the area of Winnipeg. More than 800 people were forced to flee Wednesday night when the fire came within five kilometres of Lynn Lake. The town is about 1,000 kilometres northwest of Winnipeg. The fire destroyed hydro poles, cutting off power. Almost 500 have registered in Thompson, Man., 225 kilometres southeast of Lynn Lake. Most are staying at college residences or a school while others have bunked in with friends. About 300 evacuees are in Leaf Rapids, an hour's drive southeast of the threatened town. For many of Leaf Rapids' 1,600 regular residents, it's an opportunity to return a favor. "We hosted the Leaf Rapids crew when they had their evacuation in 1989,'' said evacuee Sherron Loewen. The family she took in then invited her to stay when they heard Lynn Lake was in trouble. Loewen, 49, said the people of Leaf Rapids are wonderful, but it's natural for the evacuees to feel tension and worry.</p><p>"If you are a mother with toddlers you are going to be uptight because you may be staying in a stranger's home and you're worried about infringing on their space.'' George Fast, also staying in Leaf Rapids with friends, said the waiting is difficult. "It's very nice here,'' said Fast, 50, a retired teacher, "but everybody wants to go back.'' He and his wife threw photo albums, recipe books and mementos into their vehicle before rushing out of Lynn Lake, but forgot practical things. Leaf Rapids and Thompson have set up information centres and activities to keep anxious evacuees up to date and occupied. Elsewhere, almost 900 firefighters continued to battle a northwestern Saskatchewan fire that broke out mid-May. Called the Deer fire, it covers 300,000 hectares. High humidity and low temperatures were helping, said John Cook of the province's Prince Albert fire management centre on Saturday. Reinforcements and relief crews were being sent in over the weekend. Four fires south of Southend in the province's northeast were either under control or in the mop-up stage, he said. Searchers there were still looking for missing firefighter John Roderick Ross, 41, said Cook. No communities were endangered by the Saskatchewan fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (Thursday, Aug. 23, 4 p.m.) Parry Sound 33 forest fire is now classified as "under control" at 11,362 hectares.

Travel restrictions remain in place near the Parry Sound 33 forest fire in order to ensure Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry and emergency officials are able to continue fire suppression operations. These restrictions are in place to ensure public safety and the safety of emergency personnel working in the affected areas.

There is no access permitted within the fire perimeter as shown on the Implementation Map unless authorized by travel permit issued by Parry Sound District or Sudbury District Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

For information on travel restrictions and travel permits, please call 1-888-220-7242. For a visual representation of the affected areas please visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

A restricted fire zone remains in effect in areas north of Rosseau, northwest to Espanola and Cartier, over to the Quebec border including Temagami and Mattawa north of the Mattawa River. This includes Parry Sound, Burk's Falls, Powassan, North Bay and Greater Sudbury. For a visual representation of the affected areas please visit our interactive map Ontario.ca/forestfire.

On the afternoon of Aug. 23, there are 29 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, one fire is not yet under control. The remaining 28 fires are either being held, under control or being observed.

UPDATE (Monday, Aug. 20, 2 p.m.) On the afternoon of Aug. 20, there are 37 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, four fires are not yet under control. The remaining 33 fires are either being held, under control or being observed. There were two new fires confirmed today, at the time of this update, both near Sault Ste. Marie.

One Incident Management Team is in place in the region. It is managing Parry Sound 33, which is being held at 11,362 hectares. To find an updated map of current travel restrictions visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

Although the fire perimeter remains restricted, waterway and road restrictions were lifted effective 6 p.m. on Aug. 15. However, the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services advises the fire perimeter will remain restricted for quite some time. There is still a Notice to Airmen in place over the fire for aircraft.

Ground crews continue to extinguish hot spots within the fire perimeter and will continue moving to priority areas to search for additional hot spots.

Local residents will continue to see smoke drift from this fire over the next two or three days as weather conditions remain hot and dry.

Restricted Fire Zone in effect

A restricted fire zone remains in effect in areas north of Rosseau, northwest to Espanola and Cartier, over to the Quebec border including Temagami and Mattawa north of the Mattawa River. This includes Parry Sound, Burk's Falls, Powassan, North Bay and Greater Sudbury. For a visual representation of the affected areas please visit our interactive map Ontario.ca/forestfire.

For information on travel restrictions and travel permits, please call 1-888-220-7242. For a visual representation of the affected areas please visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

Due to the extreme fire hazard, recent heavy lightning, little precipitation and increased forest fire, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry implemented Restricted Fire Zones across a major part of the northeast and central region as outlined on the interactive fire map. This will remain in place until further notice. See the fire map for the zones covered.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ontario Ministry of Resources and Forestry expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS

For details on travel restrictions in the Parry Sound and Sudbury districts visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

Pursuant to the Emergency Area Order signed July 21, 2018, an Implementation Order has been issued by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry prohibiting access and travel in portions of Parry Sound District where there are public safety hazards as a result of increased fire activity from Parry Sound 33.

The order restricts travel, access and use in an identified area and may be modified regularly to reflect changing fire conditions. This measure has been put in place to ensure public safety while allowing fire personnel to safely and effectively suppress the fires in the identified area.

Waterways - All travel and use of the Pickerel River west of Hwy 69 to Bear Island and Key River west of Hwy 69 to Georgian Bay including all access from Georgian Bay on those water ways entering the fire perimeter or adjacent to it on its northern boundary, is prohibited during the daylight hours of 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. unless authorized by travel permit issued by Parry Sound District or Sudbury District Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

Roadways - All road access west of Hwy 69 south of Pickerel River in Mowat Township and the unsurveyed lands to the southern border of Henvey Inlet 2 Indian Reserve is prohibited unless authorized by travel permit issued by Parry Sound District or Sudbury District Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

Fire Perimeter - There is no access permitted within the fire perimeter as shown on the map unless authorized by travel permit issued by Parry Sound District or Sudbury District Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF).

If a member of the public believes that access within the restricted travel area is necessary for nonrecreational purposes, please call to 705-746-4201 to request a travel authorization permit. MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

SMOKE CONCERNS

Smoke from large fires across the region will be visible until fire activity is reduced and weather patterns change.

Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services is reminding the public that if they do see flames or smoke, please report it, and stay away from the area in the interest of public safety.

If you have questions or concerns about smoke and your health, please contact Tele Health Ontario at 1-866-797-0000.

For information about the fire situation: 705-564-6165

For inquiries about French River Provincial Park restrictions: 705-857-1630 ext 224

For inquiries about Grundy Lake Provincial Park closure: 705-383-2286 or 705-795-0803

For Parry Sound District information, including all calls related to the recommendation of these evacuations and alerts, call 705-773-4218.

For updates on highway conditions, including closures, please call 5-1-1.

See the map at Ontario.ca/forestfire

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (Thursday, Aug. 9, 3:29 p.m.) Parry Sound 33 is now listed by the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry as "being held." The size of the Parry Sound 33 fire remains at 11,362 hectares. There was no growth yesterday.

#ParrySound33 is being held at 11,362 ha. Thank-you to all the hard working fire crews, staff and emergency personnel who helped #Ontario fight this #forestfire. pic.twitter.com/SHsJJJHA9J

- ONForestFires (@ONforestfires) August 9, 2018

Aggressive fire suppression operations are ongoing throughout the entire fire area. There are 247 firefighters and support staff currently working on this incident.

On the morning of Aug. 9, there are 49 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 17 are not yet under control, 32 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There were nine new fires confirmed yesterday (Wednesday, Aug. 8), two of which had already been extinguished, as of 8 a.m. on Thursday, Aug. 9. Parry Sound 41 was not yet under control at 0.4 of a hectare, located just east of Parry Sound 33, at 8 a.m. on Thursday, Aug. 9. It started at approximately 4:33 p.m. on Wednesday, Aug. 8 and was listed as human-caused. The fire is no longer shown on the map.

So far in 2018, there have been 971 forest fires inside Ontario's fire region, according to the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. That compares to 354 fires in 2017 and a 10-year average of 567 forest fires per year.

UPDATE (Tuesday, Aug. 7, 9:40 p.m.): Though not yet under control, according to the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, Parry Sound 33 had no new growth Tuesday, August 7. The fire is holding at 11,362 hectares.

Crews continue to work the perimeter and containment around the fire is almost complete. The total perimeter is almost 120 kilometers long. There are 275 firefighters and support staff currently working on this incident. That number will continue to fluctuate as staff complete their 14 day assignment and more staff become available after days of rest.

By the evening of August 7, there were 43 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 14 are not yet under control, 29 are either being held, under control or being observed.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Tuesday, Aug. 7, 9:40 p.m.): Though not yet under control, according to the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, Parry Sound 33 had no new growth Tuesday, August 7. The fire is holding at 11,362 hectares.

Although this fire received approximately 10 millimetres of rain, extremely dry fuel conditions remain.

Firefighters took advantage of the precipitation, high humidity and low winds to continue consolidating hose lines around the perimeter. Crews continued to move inward to solidify control lines.

By the evening of Aug. 6, there were 44 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 18 are not yet under control, 26 are either being held, under control or being observed. There were four new fires confirmed on Monday, Aug. 6, two of which are already been called out, including Parry Sound 38, which was located south of Parry Sound 33. It was confirmed at 0.1 hectares and declared out on Monday, Aug. 6.

UPDATE (Sunday, Aug. 5, 10:55 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown once again, to 11,362 hectares and is still not yet under control.

The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry say it was a challenging, hot and windy day on Aug. 5 and the fire responded as they expected.

However, even with the challenges and high temperatures, the crews managed to maintain the perimeter of the fire, thanks to the placement of the hose lines. Two minor spot fires on the northeast flank were quickly contained in the morning of Aug. 5.

Crews have made excellent progress over the last few days and now have hose lines around most of the fire perimeter. More work still needs to be done as crews will work inward to solidify the control lines.

Some structure protection (sprinklers) will be removed in areas of the fire where full containment has been achieved and the threat from those structures has been removed.

Some precipitation was reported over the fire on Aug. 5 and the MNRF is hopeful that the interior of the fire receives more rain from the weather system.

Today (Aug. 6), once again, there is the potential for strong winds. Some unsettled weather may bring some scattered thunderstorms with the possibility of 10 to 15 millimetres of patchy rain. It is anticipated that temperatures will be in the mid to high 20s with high humidity. Winds could august up to 30 kilometres an hour or more.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (Saturday, Aug 4, 11:23 p.m.)

No new fires reported.

News coming from the MNRF for the Northeast region on Aug 4 is positive.

By the evening of August 4, there were 44 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 19 are not yet under control, 25 are either being held, under control or being observed.

Nine forest fires are still active to the south and west of Fort Severn in the Far North. FireRanger crews and Coastal Rangers are responding.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (Friday, Aug. 3 11:39 p.m.)

"The fire is suppressed nicely along the Key River."

This good news is coming from the most recent MNRF Northeast Region Forest Fire Situation Update.

However the fire is still more than 11,000 hectares - a single hectare is about the size of an international soccer pitch. So imaging 11,000 soccer pitches. The evacuees from Henvey are expected to be out of their homes for another week.

On Friday higher humidity helped firefighers work on the blaze, laying hose around the perimeter of the fire.

"Bucketing helicopters assisted crews in keeping the spread of the fire in check," states the MNRF release.

Read the rest of the MNRF release here:

"Helicopter bucketing helped suppress isolated pockets of higher intensity, including torching, within the perimeter of the fire.

The west side of the fire remained quiet. Crews started to work into the interior of the perimeter along the south end of Key Harbour.

Tomorrow's weather calls for higher temperatures with low humidity. The hot, dry weather, coupled with the forecasted southwesterly winds, may cause an increase in fire behaviour and test our fire lines. If such an event occurs, we have the resources to respond appropriately.

It is important to note that while good progress is being made, the fire remains active. The conditions continue to be very dry, and extreme burning conditions are still possible. Land and water restrictions remain in place at this time for protection of people, property and to allow our crews to do their work. Patrols from OPP and Conservation Officers will continue throughout the area around the fire.

We continue to work hard to manage Parry Sound 33 in order to get people back into their residences safely. We thank you for your patience and ongoing support.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Thursday, August 2, 11:40 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown to 11,185 hectares in size, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

The ministry reports that Thursday, August 2, was another great day for crews working and laying hose around the perimeter of the fire. Crews continue to make excellent progress in critical areas, especially along the northeast side of the fire near the Pickerel River. Higher winds out of the southwest today tested the northeast perimeter, but the hose lines held and kept the fire's spread in check. It is estimated that most of the east flank has been tied with hose line.

On Thursday, August 2, waterbombers and helicopters worked in conjunction with the crews to help tie off areas of activity. The fire remains south of Key Harbour, and north of the Henvey Inlet waterway. Crews are working on perimeter containment on the southeast side of the fire north of Henvey Inlet.

The west side of the fire remains unchanged; the fire remained quiet in the vicinity of Fox Island on the western perimeter. Crews continue suppression along the western flank of the fire. Structural protection continues.

Even with Thursday's winds, the fire remains approximately five kilometers away from Highway 69 and less than one kilometer south of the Pickerel River near the CN trestle bridge on the west side of Highway 69. Today's weather calls for another day of southwesterly winds.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Wednesday, August 1, 11:55 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown to 11,039 hectares in size, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

The ministry reports recent weather allowed more accurate aerial mapping of the fire and aerial ignition in the southeast added to the increased size. Fire behaviour was less active yesterday, August 1, as high humidity levels and cloud cover aided in fire suppression. Winds were generally out of the east today and changed the fire's direction of spread to the west. Hose lines on the west side of the fire held the fire's spread in check.

The ministry reports that excellent progress was made on the eastern side of the fire as crews were able to establish lines due to reduced fire behaviour when compared to previous days. Crews are laying hose from the Pickerel River south to establish a perimeter on areas that have passed over the CN line. Structural protection continues along the Key and French Rivers.

Crews continue to work the perimeter of the fire by the north and northwest of Key Harbour. Sixty firefighters remain along the east side, south of the Key River to continue perimeter containment. Aerial ignition occurred in the southeast part of the fire removing hazardous fuels and tying the fire into the northern shore of Henvey Inlet.

Even though the focus of aerial fire suppression is on the northeast side, crews continue to supress and monitor all portions of the fire. The fire remained quiet in the vicinity of Fox Island on the western perimeter. North and east winds yesterday, August 1, made for smoky conditions in communities to the south. Winds are forecasted to be out of the south today, August 2, moving to the southwest in the afternoon. The fire is approximately five kilometres west of highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of Pickerel River near the CN trestle bridge on the west side of highway 69.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Tuesday, July 31, 10:45 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown to 10,139 hectares in size, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

On Tuesday, July 31, fire behaviour was less active as humidity levels and cloud cover aided in fire suppression. The northeast portion of the fire closest to the Pickerel River was the most active part today. Winds from the southwest pushed some activity along the Pickerel, but it's still holding south of the river. The northeast corner of the fire is tucked along the west side of Little Canoe Channel. Ignition operations in that area were completed Tuesday evening, July 31, to tie the fire together and slow its progression down.

Structural protection continues. Additional protection occurred along the Key and French Rivers with sprinklers set up in noted priority zones. Crews worked the perimeter of the fire by continuing hose line north and northwest of Key Harbour. Sixty firefighters were placed along the east side, south of the Key River to continue perimeter containment. Even though the focus is on the northeast side, the ministry continues to supress and monitor all portions of the fire.

Winds are forecasted to be out of the north today, Aug, 1. The fire is approximately five kilometres west of Highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of Pickerel River.

The Municipality of Killarney issued an evacuation order for residents in the areas of Travers, Allen, Struthers, Kilpatrick, Bigwood (including Hartley Bay Road), a portion of Mowat, the Unsurveyed Area, 14 Mile Island and French River Provincial Park. For information, call the municipality at 705-287-2424.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Monday, July 30, 11:52 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire reportedly expanded by 749 hectares on Monday, reaching 8,973 hectares, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services. The fire is now approximately five kilometres west of Highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of the Pickerel River.

On Monday, July 30, winds occurred from the west/southwest. The northeast and east portions of the fire were the most active and a few of these sections progressed eastward towards the CN Line. Crews have been working hard to slow the fire's progression in this part of the fire.

Structural protection continues, with sprinklers set up on structures along the Pickerel and Key Rivers, as well as on structures along the French River on Hartley Bay Road.

Crews worked on the southeast portion to hold the perimeter and complete hose line, while water bucketing and water bombers along the east flank continued aerial suppression efforts to attempt to close in the fire.

The ministry reported that although the focus is currently on the northeast side, they continue to suppress and monitor all portions of the fire. Aerial ignition on portions of the fire near Fox Island have brought the fire to natural boundaries removing the fire hazard in this area.

The fire behaviour today, Tuesday, July 31, is expected to remain the same as Monday. High temperatures mixed with low humidity will be present on the fire site. Winds from the west/southwest will occur again into today, possibly bringing more smoke into surrounding communities and along Highway 69.

An Evacuation Alert has been issued by the Municipality of French River for the Alban area, west of the high-powered hydro lines on Highway 64. For more information on the evacuation, call the municipality at 705-898-2294 or visit frenchriver.ca.

UPDATE (Sunday, July 29, 11:45 p.m.): The ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown again, to 8,224 hectares.

Smoke may be visible in areas north and northeast of the fire due to winds from the south which may impact visibility along Highway 69 and local communities.

#ParrySound 33 is now listed at 8,224 ha. #Smoke drift may be visible in the areas north and northeast of the fire due to winds from the south, which could impact Hwy 69/400 and local communities. Please call 511 for HWY closure information. #forestfires #ontario pic.twitter.com/pZ7WpivbJT

- ONForestFires (@ONforestfires) July 29, 2018

The ministry reports northern areas of the fire held up well Sunday, July 29, west of Key Junction; however, parts of the northeast flanks south of Key Junction were quite active, but haven't yet crossed the rail line.

Structural protection was completed in Henvey Inlet. Protection for Key River and Grundy Lake will begin today. Equipment will be removed from Key Harbour as perimeter control has been completed in that area.

Aerial suppression continued yesterday with water bomber and water bucketing efforts on the east flank of the fire. Winds from the west and southwest are expected to continue today, Monday, July 30, possibly bringing more smoke into surrounding communities and along Highway 69. The fire remains six kilometres west of Highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of the Pickerel River near the CN trestle bridge on the west side of Highway 69.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (8:26 a.m. Sunday, July 29) - Parry Sound 33 had minimal growth yesterday increasing in size from 7,297 to 7,651.

In a news release sent out by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry shortly before midnight on Saturday, July 28, the fire is still listed as not under control.

Water bombers and helicopters worked most of the day on July 28, limiting movement among most areas of the fire's perimeter with generally good results.

The southwest winds are expected to continue today, possibly bringing heavy smoke conditions periodically into surrounding communities along Highway 69. The fire remains approximately seven kilometres west of Highway 69 and three kilometres south of the Pickerel River and is nearly 100 kilometres north of Parry Sound.

For most of Saturday, July 28, winds from the southwest continued, keeping the northeast side as the most active part of the fire. Priority remains along the northeast side of the fire with fingers extending toward the CN rail line as minimal movement occurred across the tracks. Additionally, there was minimal growth along the southwest portion of the fire.

Hose lay and containment will continue along the northern portion as crews look to secure that area.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (8:20 a.m. Saturday, July 28) - Parry Sound 33 is still not under control and continues to grow.

In a news release sent out at 12:35 a.m. on July 28, the fire has grown to 7,297 hectares. Due to the southwest winds, the northeast side is the most active part of the fire.

The northeast side of the fire is the focus for Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry water bombers and helicopter bucketing, as it is closest to the rail line and more populated areas.

There has been minimal growth on the southwest end of the fire.

Southwest winds are expected to continue tomorrow, possibly bringing heavy smoke conditions periodically into surrounding commentates and along Highway 69. The fire is approximately seven kilometres west of Highway 69 and three kilometres south of the Pickerel River.

Wildfire crews continue to make progress around the southwest side of the perimeter by laying hose lines and actively attacking hot spots in the Key Harbour. That area is protected and the MNRF does not expect any movement in that area over the next few days.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 p.m. Thursday, July 26): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports Parry Sound 33 is still not under control and growing.

According to the ministry in a news release dated 11:55 p.m., Thursday, July 26, by the evening of July 26 there were 45 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held, under control or being observed. Of the 15 not under control, Parry Sound 33 is one of them.

As of July 26, the fire is estimated at 6,760 hectares and there was minimal grown on the north, west and south end of the fire. The implementation order and all access restriction, including water access restriction, remain in place. The southwest winds are expected to continue today, possibly gusting from 30 to 40 kilometres per hour. Unfortunately, there is minimal precipitation in the forecast.

"Crews continue to make excellent progress around the southwest side of the perimeter, laying hose and working on hotspots north and south of Key River," reads the release."Today's focus was on the north and east flank of the fire, which were once again active due to sustained southern and southwesterly winds. The fire did put on some growth along the east flank, with one area of the fire crossing both Tower Lake and impacting the CN rail in one location."

Continued growth of the fire is expected on the northeast flank today. Water bombers and helicopters worked most of the day halting or slowing the spread of the fire. Values protection, or sprinklers, continue to be placed along Pickerel River and began in Henvey Inlet as a precautionary measure.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 a.m. Wednesday, July 25): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Fire has expanded Northeast region restricted fire zone.

Due to strong, warmer and drier lake effect winds the ministry required aerial fire suppression yesterday, July 25, as fire activity increased. As a result of the the southwest winds, smoke was pushed across Highway 69 and into some communities to the east of the fire.

Resources yesterday included CL415 water bombers, two bird dog aircraft, heavy helicopters T802 amphibious aircraft and ground crews, the ministry reports.

Additional crews from Mexico arrived on the fire today, bringing the total number of firefighters helping to suppress the fire to 90. Values protection, or sprinklers, will continue to be put in place on structures along the Pickerel River today.

"Given the unpredictability of the fire, all access restrictions, including water restrictions, remain in place for the foreseeable future," reads a ministry press release. "In the interest of public safety, on July 21, 2018 the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF)'s Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area below impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only: All areas ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay."

There is also a recommendation by the ministry Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

By the evening of July 25 there were 50 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 16 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There were two new fires confirmed in the region today. Hearst 14, located approximately 42 kilometres south of Hearst, is two hectares and not yet under control. Two crews provided initial attack on the fire with aerial suppression support. Wawa 11 is being held at 0.1 hectares 75 kilometres southeast of Longlac.

(Tuesday, July 24, 11:10 p.m.):The fire is expected to remain relatively quiet for the next couple of days.

"However, fire conditions and behaviour can change quickly. Crews continue to monitor weather and fire behaviour closely. Residents will see smoke in the area as crews continue suppression efforts. Values protection have been put in place in Key Harbour, along parts of the south side of Pickerel River and along a portion of the train tracks east of the fire."

A total of eight helicopters worked the fire on July 24.

As of July 24 the fire was at 5,612 hectares and still not under control.

The cause of the fire was originally stated as "human" on the MNR's website but that classification has since been removed, McCool said, to avoid public speculation.

"Because the cause is still unknown at this time and it is under investigation."

(11:59 p.m., Monday, July 23): The Key River forest fire, known as Parry Sound 33, is now covering an area of 5,612 hectares and the restricted fire zone has been expanded to north of Rosseau.

According to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services, Parry Sound 33 saw aerial fire suppression again on Monday, July 23. CL415s dropped water on the fire which was remapped at 5,612 hectares. Three heavy helicopters bucketed water to reduce the fire's intensity and co-ordinated with ground crews.

On July 21, the MNRF's Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only.

There is also a recommendation by the MNRF Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

In addition, the MNRF's Sudbury district has recommended that all residents along Hartley Bay Road be placed on an evacuation alert, pending changes to the fire situation.

The Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) and Conservation Officers have been on site helping notify the public of the situation, and facilitating this evacuation.

Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services (AFFES) has also been advised by Ontario Parks that the French River Provincial Park is fully closed west of Highway 69/400. All campers have been or are being evacuated. Ontario Parks has also suspended permit sales for the French River Delta and Pickerel River areas and are restricting entry to park users (everything west of Highway 69/400).

Henvey Inlet First Nation declared a state of emergency as a precautionary measure. As of July 22, the community has successfully and safely evacuated all of its community members, who are receiving accommodation and food.

By the evening of July 23 there were 55 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 21 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There was only one new start in the region today. Sudbury 92 located near Johnnie Lake in Killarney Provincial Park covers 0.1 of a hectare and is already under control.

(CP) _ A blazing forest fire has forced more than 350 people from the tiny aboriginal communities of Turnor Lake and Birch Narrows in northern Saskatchewan.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Flames approached within metres of the villages located about 600 kilometres northwest of Saskatoon Tuesday.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>It was very, very smoky in the community,'' said Earl Greyeyes of the provincial fire centre.</p><p> Winds from the west actually just helped fuel the fire. They pushed it along towards the community.''</p><p>Evacuations began Monday afternoon as children, the elderly, and those with respiratory problems such as asthma were taken to nearby Buffalo Narrows, La Loche and Meadow Lake.</p><p>The rest of the people in the communities were evacuated Tuesday morning.</p><p>Many are staying at the Meadow Lake Alliance Church, about a three and a half hour drive to the south, where they will sleep in a gymnasium on beds trucked in from North Battleford, Sask., said Suzanne Jost, church secretary.</p><p>She said the evacuees could end up staying at the church for several days, given the current conditions.</p><p> Just when you think the fire is out, it is not _ and the weather is so hot,'' she said.</p><p>Greyeyes said the fire has already consumed more than 200 square kilometres of timber.</p><p>RCMP Sgt. Gord Wellar said no one is in danger and the fire appeared to have skirted the communities Tuesday night.</p><p> The evacuation has taken place and there is no danger to residents,'' Wellar said. We have been very lucky.''</p><p>Water bombers and fire crews are working to try and contain the blaze.</p><p>Saskatchewan Environment has also set up industrial sprinkler systems on buildings and in trees to shower the village with water.</p><p>As of Tuesday, there were 59 forest fires burning in the province.</p><p>Meanwhile, in Alberta, fire officials have announced plans to enact a fire ban over most of the northern and central parts of the province Wednesday. The ban will include the use of fireworks, firecrackers and sparklers.</p><p>There were 57 fires burning in Saskathcewan Tuesday, including 29 which were burning out of control. There were 30 new fires in the past 24 hours.</p><p>(Saskatoon StarPhoenix)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20020625CPCPG3974</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2002</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:464X-FDH0-01G6-91J0-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="351"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2002 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="25" month="06" year="2002"><dateText>June 25, 2002 Tuesday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>ENVIRONMENT; urn:contentItem:564D-JJC1-JBVR-33RM-00000-00Crews from Alaska, Ontario arrive in northern Alberta to help fight forest fire2012-07-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:46ZLexisNexisWEATHER,PRAIRIES/BCCrews from Alaska, Ontario arrive in northern Alberta to help fight forest fireFirefighters from Alaska, Ontario land in northern AlbertaThe Canadian Press

ZAMA CITY, Alta. - Firefighters from Alaska and Ontario landed Monday in northern Alberta to help fight a forest fire threatening an isolated hamlet.

Wildfire information officer Heather Hawkins said 11 firefighters from Alaska and eight from Ontario, along with helicopters and other equipment, were joining more than 300 firefighters who have taken shifts battling the blaze, which is 12 kilometres northeast of Zama City.

Some crews arrived last week from the Yukon and New Brunswick.

About 160 residents were forced last Tuesday to leave the community, located about 930 kilometres north of Edmonton.

They were not being allowed to return home and remained holed up in hotels in High Level, said John Klassen, an official with Mackenzie County.

People from the nearby Dene Tha' First Nation also remained out of their homes. All 408 people on the reserve voluntarily left last week due to smoke. They were also staying in High Level.

The haze from the wildfire - and from another 15 fires burning out of control in the northern part of the province - drifted into Edmonton and into western Saskatchewan late last week.

An air quality advisory issued Friday by Alberta Health Services for the Edmonton area was lifted Monday. But it remained in effect for the northern region.

Hawkins was expecting a shift in hot, dry weather to soon come to the rescue.

"We're expecting some of that rain we've seen in Edmonton to move up into northern Alberta ... and then more widespread rain Wednesday, which will certainly help the situation."

She said the fire was sparked by lightning, the cause of half of summer forest fires. It has so far destroyed almost 1,300 square kilometres of timber and bush.

Another fire raging 15 kilometres southeast of the hamlet of La Crete has destroyed just over 25 square kilometres of forest. It earlier shut down the busy Mackenzie Highway and a voluntary evacuation was temporarily in place.

Hawkins said that blaze, named the Bear Creek fire, was classified as being held and firefighters had 80 per cent of it contained.

"With the current resources and weather forecasted, we're not expecting it to grow significantly."

urn:contentItem:4TBN-P6S0-TX4V-K04K-00000-00Nevada governor chides Forest Service for handling of spreading forest fire2008-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:46ZLexisNexisFOREIGN GENERAL NEWSNevada governor chides Forest Service for handling of spreading forest fireMARTIN GRIFFITHAP

RENO, Nev. _ Gov. Jim Gibbons has criticized U.S. Forest Service officials' decision to let a wildfire in northeast Nevada burn unchecked for two weeks, saying it allowed the blaze to ''get out of control'' and substantially spread.

Federal officials initiated efforts to combat the lightning-caused fire Aug. 21, when it began spreading outside the scenic, remote Jarbidge Wilderness Area of the Humboldt-Toiyabe National Forest near the Idaho line.

Since then, the fire has grown from 33 square kilometres to almost 200 square kilometres. It also has moved from about 30 kilometres to a mere six kilometres of the nearest town of Jarbidge.

The blaze was 30 per cent contained Sunday. No homes were threatened, and no major injuries were reported.

''The forest fire that we have today was allowed to get out of control, knowing the dangers of the fuel loading and the weather conditions _ dry, hot, windy,'' Gibbons said.

''That is an extremely dangerous combination that I think should have sent red flags up the moment the fire started to the Forest Service.'' he said.

''If they disregarded those, then the Forest Service bears complete responsibility for the fire getting out of control and now reaching (its current size),'' the Republican governor said.

Humboldt-Toiyabe Supervisor Ed Monnig said the agency initially tried to fight the fire, but later decided not to suppress it after concluding the area's rugged terrain would put firefighters at risk.

The agency allowed the fire to burn as part of a management practice called ''wildland fire use,'' which is used to manage lightning-caused fires in remote areas where fire is a natural component of the ecosystem.

Fire experts had predicted there would be less than a two per cent chance of the fire escaping the wilderness, Monnig said.

''We weighed the firefighter safety issues against the values that we were trying to protect and decided to take a less aggressive strategy to managing the fire,'' Monnig told The Associated Press.

''Unfortunately, we had several strong wind events that have pushed the fire beyond anything we predicted.

''Firefighter safety is a huge concern when I look at deploying forces. We have lost 19 firefighters in wildland fires (across the country) to date this season,'' he said Sunday.

The fire area contains many insect- and disease-killed trees that would have eventually burned, added fire information officer Bob Summerfield.

''The fire is playing its natural role in the wilderness,'' Summerfield said.

''It's better to let it burn this year under moderate fire conditions rather than another year under extreme fire conditions. It's cleaning up dead fuels in there that present a fire hazard.''
