B2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>RESIDENTSFLEE AS FOREST FIRE RAGES ON;<br/>FIREFIGHTERS BATTLE OTTAWA-AREA BLAZE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MARK BRENNAE, THE CANADIAN PRESS</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>ALMONTE, ONT.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Dozens of homes were evacuated yesterday as firefighters and water bomber pilots raced to squelch a forest fire burning out of control just west of Ottawa.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Fire trucks from 12 municipalities lined Highway 44 outside this picturesque village about 50 kilometres from the capital as two airplanes dumped water on the blaze.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The fire is too hot to attack it on the ground," said Paul Asmis, fire chief for West Carleton Township. "(It's) crowning and jumping ahead of itself in 500-foot (150-metre) intervals."</p><p>Asmis did not expect the flames would be brought under control by nightfall.</p><p>It was hoped that two more water bombers would arrive from Quebec.</p><p>The blaze broke out around 1 p.m. and moved about 3.65 kilometres every hour along a six-kilometre stretch comprised mostly of bush, consuming more than 150 hectares of land.</p><p>It moved easterly at first but veered north as the wind shifted.</p><p>More than 120 firefighters tried to keep it from reaching a residential enclave about nine kilometres east of where it started, said a dispatcher.</p><p>"I think we're getting some progress on it but it's hard to tell right now," said Chris Powers, chief of the Nepean Fire Department near Ottawa.</p><p>Protective foam was sprayed on about 30 houses in the fire's path as fire trucks stood by.</p><p>"It's still a dangerous situation," Powers said as the evening wore on.</p><p>Richard MacLean, his wife and two of his three children sat in lawn chairs a safe distance away, watching flames creep toward their home in Carp on the Almonte border.</p><p>"I'm very worried," he said. "I spent a good part of the winter clearing trees in there. I must have cut three or four hundred trees from the ice storm last year."</p><p>OPP officers told MacLean and his family to evacuate the house where they've lived for less than two years. They fled after turning off the power.</p><p>"You're worried. Your house is your home. It's your castle."</p><p>Smoke could be seen for kilometres and ash from the fire was falling as far away as Kanata, a western suburb.</p><p>There were no early reports of injuries. No homes had been destroyed by late afternoon.</p><p>"The fire is . . . definitely not under control by any means," said one OPP officer. "No word yet on how long it might take.</p><p>"It's dry. That's one reason the fire spread so much."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Photo by Tony Caldwell, The Ottawa Sun; Volunteer firefighter Randy Scheal C04</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo><nitf:fixture xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/">News</nitf:fixture></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Light winds, rain aid in forest-fire battles</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Carol Harrington</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>HILLCREST, ALTA.</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Light winds were blowing a raging wildfire parallel to threatened towns in the Crowsnest Pass yesterday, allowing crews to build fire lines to buffer populated areas in the mountainous region of southwestern Alberta.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Lost Creek fire, which forced 100 people from their homes and had more than 1,000 on alert to leave on an hour's notice, grew to 115 square kilometres.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Officials were worried the fire, which was about one kilometre away from a steep valley, could shoot down the hollow toward the closest towns of Blairmore and Coleman, with more than 4,400 residents.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Canadian Press</p></bodyText></section><p>"Sometimes topography is more important than the wind," said Kim Morton of Alberta Sustainable Resource Development.</p><p>Water bombers dumped chemical retardant south of Coleman so that heavy-equipment operators could cut a path toward the fire.</p><p>The fire hazard was so extreme the Alberta government banned public access to a 1,400 square-kilometre area south of Blairmore. Less severe restrictions were imposed on an area running 150 kilometres north of the threatened communities.</p><p>The fire, burning out of control since last Wednesday, originated at the Lynx Creek campground, where charred trailers litter the grounds. Several kilometres north of the camp, about 100 residents in the town of Hillcrest were evacuated last weekend.</p><p>Six days after the fire began, officials were still investigating how it started.</p><p>The wildfire is costing the province about $1 million a day for 650 firefighters supported by 18 helicopters, seven water bombers and 30 bulldozers.</p><p>Logging crews, meanwhile, have hacked away dense bush and trees along a nearby natural gas pipeline to clear a 60-metre wide swath of bare earth to act as a fire break.</p><p>Many of the people on alert to possibly leave their homes packed some belongings and nervously awaited developments.</p><p>Hot, dry conditions were also causing headaches for crews fighting an out-of-control fire in Jasper National Park yesterday.</p><p>Traffic on Highway 16, the main road into the park, faced delays due to blowing smoke from the fire.</p><p>In Thompson, Man., rain brought much-needed relief for crews battling a big forest fire south of the city. The fire has consumed 400 square kilometres of forest since being sparked by lightning more than two weeks ago.</p><p>In the Northwest Territories, crews continued fighting wildfires near several communities.</p><p>More than 180 wildfires continued to burn in British Columbia.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5X8M-VNW1-DY91-K0NN-00000-00Boom to bust in Fort Mac2019-10-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:46ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B1Boom to bust in Fort MacResidents flood food bank after oil market bottoms out, city recovers from forest fireKevin Orland and Chris Fournier Bloomberg

Dan Edwards watched Fort McMurray turn into the insolvency capital of Canada from a warehouse on King Street, home to the Wood Buffalo Food Bank.

Ten years ago, about 2,000 people came by every month for jars of peanut butter and cans of soup. Now, he and his staff help feed four times that. Before, the clientele was mostly folks struggling to pay rents that shot up during the oil boom. Today, it's often men and women who were living high before the bust. Sometimes, they pull up in shiny pickups purchased just a year or two ago.

"You never know who's going to walk through your door," said Edwards, the food bank's director. "Individuals that have degrees and education and skills, but the jobs just aren't what they were."

Once the booming heart of the country's energy industry, the little city of 75,000 in northeastern Alberta has become a showcase for the debt troubles many Canadians are facing. Fat paycheques and generous overtime earlier this decade fuelled big spending on customized pickups and million-dollar homes. With work drying up, the bills have come due.

Consumer insolvency filings in the Fort McMurray district climbed 39 per cent in 2018, the largest percentage increase in Canada, federal data show. Claims against property, the first step in the foreclosure process, surged almost tenfold over the past three years, according to court records. The city's 90-day delinquency rate on nonmortgage loans climbed to 1.75 per cent in the second quarter, compared with 1.12 per cent nationally, according to Equifax Canada.

The five-year slump that's cut oil prices in half since 2014 has been a driver in the bust. What piled on the pain was a crippling shortage of pipelines out of the McMurray Formation, a massive reserve of crude-laden oilsands.

Plans for new lines have been squelched or stalled by court challenges from an array of opponents, including U.S. activists who view the oilsands as a "carbon bomb" that will one day unleash a climate catastrophe.

Stewardship of the energy industry has become a central issue of Canada's federal election. The Conservative party has portrayed itself as a champion of the sector and pledges to remove regulations Prime Minister Justin Trudeau implemented. The Liberals, meanwhile, are trying to strike a balance between developing Alberta's energy resources and making Canada a leader in combating climate change.

In May, after five years at Suncor Energy Inc.'s Fort Hills oilsands mine, Steve Richardson was let go, like many others in the industry.

Richardson, 42, earned around six figures most years as a heavy equipment operator. For about 10 months, he commuted from Vancouver Island in British Columbia, with Suncor paying for most of his flights and putting him up in a camp near the work site. He'd dig trenches for 14 days, then go home for seven.

After the travel reimbursements stopped, he moved his family to a small town about a seven-hour drive from Fort Mac, so he could keep the job. Now, he's doing short-term work and making economies where he can, such as cancelling his family's cable subscription.

"I spend a lot of time wondering what the next job is going to be," Richardson said. He's thankful he resisted buying boats or taking vacations on credit, as many of his friends did. "I never got into all the toys. I'm kind of fortunate that way, that I didn't have to sell everything off like some other people. I've seen a lot of that. It's like a fire sale."

The energy business has long been core to the local economy. Commercial production got off the ground in the 1940s, but the oil was always a devil to recover. It's mired in a sludge that has to be tediously pumped out or strip-mined in open pits. Either way, the process is technologically challenging.

The potential, though, is staggering. With 165.4 billion barrels, these oilsands are the world's third-largest proven reserve, trailing only those in Venezuela and Saudi Arabia. As oil prices were climbing from 2004 to 2014, the industry invested $210.1 billion, more than last year's combined total capital spending by all of the companies in the Dow Jones industrial average. Over those 10 years, oilsands output more than doubled, to 2.2 million barrels a day. Canada shot up from the world's eighth-largest oil-producing nation to the fifth-largest, overtaking Iran, Mexico and Norway. It was a heady time.

John Hickey, a mechanic who works on used oil-industry vehicles, lost his house in the wildfire. Too many, he said, "made a lifestyle based on an economy that wasn't sustainable."

urn:contentItem:46YX-VM30-01G6-82DW-00000-00<published>2001-05-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BC-Alta-Forest-Fire, ; Eds: Updates with return of Chisholm evacuees, will be Writethru; See CP Photo; INDEX: Environment, Social, Forestry, Health; HL:Chisholm families endure midnight evacuation as Alta forest fire approaches</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>By Darcy Henton</p><p nitf:lede="true">EDMONTON (CP) - Four families in the northern Alberta community of Chisholm were rousted from their beds when a forest fire raged perilously close to their homes early Saturday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- About 12 residents of the tiny hamlet, about 150 km north of Edmonton, were evacuated about midnight local time when flames from a massive fire crept within 400 metres, said Barb Toker, an Alberta fire spokeswoman.</p><p nitf:lede="true">During the night, fire destroyed a garage and an older model vehicle south of the community, but no homes have been burned, she said. Six bulldozers and 50 firefighters defended the hamlet's southern limits Saturday as water bombers hammered back the flames enough for the evacuation order to be lifted later in the afternoon.</p><p>"The fire has been contained to a safe perimeter,'' said Susan Mcmanus, a spokeswoman for Alberta Sustainable Resource Development. "Residents are not at immediate risk.''</p><p>She said she was hopeful those residents who opted to return would get a more restful sleep Saturday night.</p><p>A fireguard has been established around the perimeter of the town and a municipal fire truck waited on standby to protect the buildings in the community. Toker said it was complemented by a rapid fire unit that uses compressed foam to protect the structures in the community.</p><p>Firefighters are also trying to protect another 12 unoccupied summer cottages in the area.</p><p>Chisholm is on the northern boundary of the 120 square kilometre fire that is now under attack from 200 firefighters and a fleet of helicopters, planes and heavy equipment.</p><p>Thirteen residents of Flatbush, about 20 km to the south, remain on evacuation alert, but winds blowing out of the east Saturday have given them some respite.</p><p>"If necessary they will be instructed when it may be time to leave,'' Toker said from the scene as two CL-215 water bombers roared overhead.</p><p>About 30 people evacuated from farms north of Flatbush Friday have been allowed to return to their homes, but remain on evacuation alert, she said.</p><p>"We're dealing with a fire and conditions that could change at a moment's notice,'' she added. "While we're doing good work out here right now, we're taking every precaution. This is the largest fire we've had in Alberta this year.''</p><p>The Chisholm residents had been billeted with friends and family in the neighbouring towns of Smith and Slave Lake.</p><p>Access to the community was blocked Friday night by manned barricades that were lifted about 3 p.m. local time Saturday, said Mcmanus.</p><p>Meanwhile, Transport Canada investigators were able to return on Saturday to the scene of a plane crash that killed two people who had been helping fight another fire Friday.</p><p>RCMP removed the bodies of the unidentified pilot and passenger of a forest fire spotter plane that crashed on the edge of fire burning northeast of Red Earth Creek, but had to evacuate the area when the fire came within a half kilometre.</p><p>The Cessna went down in dense forest in a hilly area.</p><p>Police said smoke had reduced visibility in the area.</p><p>Nearly 500 firefighters continue to fight 18 fires in the province after one of the driest winters in Alberta history. Five fires, including the Chisholm fire, continued to burn out of control Saturday.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata after forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>(CP)</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>GERALDTON</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>GERALDTON (CP) - More than 450 Ojibwas evacuated a week ago from their remote Northern Ontario community because of a forest fire have started to return.</p><p nitf:lede="true">By mid-afternoon yesterday, a chartered airplane had returned about 40 people to Webequie, said Dave Slater, spokesman for the Ontario ministry of natural resources.</p><p>Additional planes were to carry another 410 people on a one-hour flight more than 300 kilometres (185 miles) north to their home, Slater said.</p><p>"The planes will be flying up, back and loading up again," he said.</p><p>Firefighters have contained the 24-hectare (59-acre) blaze that destroyed a sawmill and six storage sheds at the edge of Webequie, which lies on the Winisk River flowing into Hudson Bay.</p><p>Another 250 Ojibwas, also evacuated to Geraldton from Fort Hope and Lansdowne House, midway between the Manitoba border and James Bay, are waiting to return home.</p><p>More than 100 people were evacuated from Fort Hope, a community of about 800, because of smoke from three nearby fires that had destroyed 3,400 hectares (8,400 acres) of spruce and brush.</p><p>A total of 159 elderly, young and sick were evacuated from Lansdowne House, leaving about 40 residents and 50 provincial firefighters to fight a 400-hectare fire.</p><p>Attawapiskat Lake separated the community from the fire, and helped contain it, ministry spokesmen said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">TSTAR1989</dc:source><dc:identifier (CP) _ A man whose dropped cigarette started a devastating fire that raged out of control and destroyed dozens of homes in 2003 has been found guilty.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Provincial court Judge William Sundhu said Mike Barre "was not paying attention'' when he stomped out a cigarette near his southern Interior home.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Barre, 52, was charged with dropping a burning substance within one kilometre of a forest.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Despite the devastation, many area residents stood behind Barre. About 1,400 people recently signed a petition calling on the Crown to stay the charge against Barre.</p><p>One of the organizers of the petition said it was designed to show support for the man many believe did all he could in the circumstances to stop the fire from spreading.</p><p>Barre admitted during his trial that the fire started just moments after he stomped out a cigarette on a path behind his house. The fire destroyed homes and businesses and forced people to evacuate. It eventually grew to more than 260 square kilometres in size and cost the B.C. Ministry of Forests more than $31 million to fight.</p><p>Homes and businesses in the tiny municipalities north of Kamloops of McLure, Barriere, Louis Creek and other surrounding communities were evacuated.</p><p>In one afternoon, 73 homes and a major sawmill were destroyed in Louis Creek.</p><p>Outside the court, Barre walked briskly away from reporters, saying only: "I'm glad when it's going to be all over.''</p><p>Crown counsel Jonathan Oliphant and Barre's lawyer, John Hogg, both agreed afterwards that "it was a well-reasoned judgment.''</p><p>Oliphant said the verdict "reflected the evidence we heard.''</p><p>He expressed hope that the verdict would act as a deterrence.</p><p>"You just can't be dropping cigarettes in a forest when it is as tinder dry as it was that year,'' said Oliphant.</p><p>The Crown counsel said it was likely that Barre would receive a fine, likely in the range of $1,500, when he is sentenced Nov. 29.</p><p>"I hope this makes people think twice. It raised public awareness and I hope this teaches people to be careful.</p><p>Hogg said his client has "gone through hell'' in the more than two years since the huge forest fire.</p><p>"He's felt worse. He felt worse early on. He's had to take counselling because of it. He's felt bad, bad and bad the whole way.''</p><p>The judge put the blame on Barre.</p><p>"The evidence strongly leans to the conclusion that Mr. Barre was not paying attention . . . and failed to direct his mind to the importance of discarding and putting out his cigarette in an appropriate place and manner,'' the judge said in his written ruling.</p><p>The judge said Barre's initial statements to authorities immediately after the blaze, in which he took responsibility for the fire, differed from his testimony in court, where he said he had butted the cigarette out properly.</p><p>"I do not believe him and the manner in which he claims to have put out the cigarette,'' the judge said. "He did not take reasonable care in putting out his cigarette.''</p><p>The judge found that the fire started shortly after Barre stomped out a cigarette on a path behind his house.</p><p>The area was tinder dry, in the middle of an explosive fire season, with forest fire ratings in the high to extreme category.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Cabin owners are being allowed to retrieve valuables but not to stay.</p><p>Officials are now building a second fire line to the north of the first one.</p><p>The 16,000 Yellowknife residents are not thought to be in any immediate fire danger.</p><p>About 100 firefighters continue to fight the blaze, working long hours in rough country.</p><p>They're being helped by nine helicopters and six water bombers.</p><p>Although the trees being burned have little commercial value, Lepine said the area sees heavy recreational use from Yellowknife residents.</p><p>The fire has also closed part of the highway leading east from the territorial capital</p><p>Smoke and ash continue to taint the air in Yellowknife.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5T3G-1TY1-F105-64HR-00000-00Parry Sound 33 remains held; crews continue to extinguish hot spots2018-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:46ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Parry Sound 33 remains held; crews continue to extinguish hot spots

PARRY SOUND -UPDATE (Monday, Aug. 20, 2 p.m.) On the afternoon of Aug. 20, there are 37 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, four fires are not yet under control. The remaining 33 fires are either being held, under control or being observed. There were two new fires confirmed today, at the time of this update, both near Sault Ste. Marie.

One Incident Management Team is in place in the region. It is managing Parry Sound 33, which is being held at 11,362 hectares. To find an updated map of current travel restrictions visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

Although the fire perimeter remains restricted, waterway and road restrictions were lifted effective 6 p.m. on Aug. 15. However, the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services advises the fire perimeter will remain restricted for quite some time. There is still a Notice to Airmen in place over the fire for aircraft.

Ground crews continue to extinguish hot spots within the fire perimeter and will continue moving to priority areas to search for additional hot spots.

Local residents will continue to see smoke drift from this fire over the next two or three days as weather conditions remain hot and dry.

Restricted Fire Zone in effect

A restricted fire zone remains in effect in areas north of Rosseau, northwest to Espanola and Cartier, over to the Quebec border including Temagami and Mattawa north of the Mattawa River. This includes Parry Sound, Burk's Falls, Powassan, North Bay and Greater Sudbury. For a visual representation of the affected areas please visit our interactive map Ontario.ca/forestfire.

Travel restrictions

In order to ensure MNRF and emergency officials are able to continue fire suppression operations in areas affected by large forest fires, travel restrictions remain in place near the Parry Sound 33, North Bay 72 and Pembroke 6 forest fires. These restrictions are in place to ensure public safety and the safety of emergency personnel working in the affected areas. Although some restrictions have been removed, others remain in place. For information on travel restrictions and travel permits, please call 1-888-220-7242. For a visual representation of the affected areas please visit Ontario.ca/forestfire.

UPDATE (Sunday, Aug. 19, 5:27 p.m.) On the afternoon of Sunday, Aug. 19, there are 38 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, three fires are not yet under control. The remaining 35 fires are either being held, under control or being observed. There were three new fires confirmed in northeastern Ontario on Sunday, with one already being declared out. The other two, near Timmins and Kapuskasing, were under aerial suppression at the time of this report.

Parry Sound 33 fire remains 11,362 hectares in size and is being held.

Local residents will continue to see smoke drift from this fire over the next two to three days as weather conditions remain hot an dry. Ground crews continue to extinguish hot spots within the fire perimeter and will continue moving to priority areas to search for additional hot spots.

RESTRICTED FIRE ZONES

Due to the extreme fire hazard, recent heavy lightning, little precipitation and increased forest fire, the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry implemented Restricted Fire Zones across a major part of the northeast and central region as outlined on the interactive fire map. This will remain in place until further notice. See the fire map for the zones covered.

During a Restricted Fire Zone, the use of open fires - such as campfires, or burning of brush or debris is restricted. Failure to comply could result in fines of up to $25,000 and three months in jail, as well as financial responsibility for the costs incurred in fighting a forest fire.

Portable gas or propane stoves are permitted for use for cooking or warmth, though they should be closely monitored. Portable charcoal barbecues and Hibachis are not permitted unless within 100 metres of a dwelling, or within an organized campground.

Commercial campground operators may allow their guests to enjoy campfires during a Restricted Fire Zone period provided they meet certain conditions in the Outdoor Fires Regulation (207/96).

The Restricted Fire Zone is a temporary measure to reduce the number of new human-caused wildfires as the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ontario Ministry of Resources and Forestry expects the elevated forest fire hazard to continue into the foreseeable future.

MNRF will review the request for access based on the rationale provided, local fire activity, and the potential fire risk.

SMOKE CONCERNS

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (Thursday, Aug. 9, 3:29 p.m.) Parry Sound 33 is now listed by the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry as "being held." The size of the Parry Sound 33 fire remains at 11,362 hectares. There was no growth yesterday.

#ParrySound33 is being held at 11,362 ha. Thank-you to all the hard working fire crews, staff and emergency personnel who helped #Ontario fight this #forestfire. pic.twitter.com/SHsJJJHA9J

- ONForestFires (@ONforestfires) August 9, 2018

Aggressive fire suppression operations are ongoing throughout the entire fire area. There are 247 firefighters and support staff currently working on this incident.

On the morning of Aug. 9, there are 49 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 17 are not yet under control, 32 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There were nine new fires confirmed yesterday (Wednesday, Aug. 8), two of which had already been extinguished, as of 8 a.m. on Thursday, Aug. 9. Parry Sound 41 was not yet under control at 0.4 of a hectare, located just east of Parry Sound 33, at 8 a.m. on Thursday, Aug. 9. It started at approximately 4:33 p.m. on Wednesday, Aug. 8 and was listed as human-caused. The fire is no longer shown on the map.

So far in 2018, there have been 971 forest fires inside Ontario's fire region, according to the Aviation Forest Fire and Emergency Services branch of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry. That compares to 354 fires in 2017 and a 10-year average of 567 forest fires per year.

UPDATE (Tuesday, Aug. 7, 9:40 p.m.): Though not yet under control, according to the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, Parry Sound 33 had no new growth Tuesday, August 7. The fire is holding at 11,362 hectares.

Crews continue to work the perimeter and containment around the fire is almost complete. The total perimeter is almost 120 kilometers long. There are 275 firefighters and support staff currently working on this incident. That number will continue to fluctuate as staff complete their 14 day assignment and more staff become available after days of rest.

By the evening of August 7, there were 43 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 14 are not yet under control, 29 are either being held, under control or being observed.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Tuesday, Aug. 7, 9:40 p.m.): Though not yet under control, according to the Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services of the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry, Parry Sound 33 had no new growth Tuesday, August 7. The fire is holding at 11,362 hectares.

Although this fire received approximately 10 millimetres of rain, extremely dry fuel conditions remain.

Firefighters took advantage of the precipitation, high humidity and low winds to continue consolidating hose lines around the perimeter. Crews continued to move inward to solidify control lines.

By the evening of Aug. 6, there were 44 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 18 are not yet under control, 26 are either being held, under control or being observed. There were four new fires confirmed on Monday, Aug. 6, two of which are already been called out, including Parry Sound 38, which was located south of Parry Sound 33. It was confirmed at 0.1 hectares and declared out on Monday, Aug. 6.

UPDATE (Sunday, Aug. 5, 10:55 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown once again, to 11,362 hectares and is still not yet under control.

The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry say it was a challenging, hot and windy day on Aug. 5 and the fire responded as they expected.

However, even with the challenges and high temperatures, the crews managed to maintain the perimeter of the fire, thanks to the placement of the hose lines. Two minor spot fires on the northeast flank were quickly contained in the morning of Aug. 5.

Crews have made excellent progress over the last few days and now have hose lines around most of the fire perimeter. More work still needs to be done as crews will work inward to solidify the control lines.

Some structure protection (sprinklers) will be removed in areas of the fire where full containment has been achieved and the threat from those structures has been removed.

Some precipitation was reported over the fire on Aug. 5 and the MNRF is hopeful that the interior of the fire receives more rain from the weather system.

Today (Aug. 6), once again, there is the potential for strong winds. Some unsettled weather may bring some scattered thunderstorms with the possibility of 10 to 15 millimetres of patchy rain. It is anticipated that temperatures will be in the mid to high 20s with high humidity. Winds could august up to 30 kilometres an hour or more.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (Saturday, Aug 4, 11:23 p.m.)

No new fires reported.

News coming from the MNRF for the Northeast region on Aug 4 is positive.

By the evening of August 4, there were 44 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 19 are not yet under control, 25 are either being held, under control or being observed.

Nine forest fires are still active to the south and west of Fort Severn in the Far North. FireRanger crews and Coastal Rangers are responding.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (Friday, Aug. 3 11:39 p.m.)

"The fire is suppressed nicely along the Key River."

This good news is coming from the most recent MNRF Northeast Region Forest Fire Situation Update.

However the fire is still more than 11,000 hectares - a single hectare is about the size of an international soccer pitch. So imaging 11,000 soccer pitches. The evacuees from Henvey are expected to be out of their homes for another week.

On Friday higher humidity helped firefighers work on the blaze, laying hose around the perimeter of the fire.

"Bucketing helicopters assisted crews in keeping the spread of the fire in check," states the MNRF release.

Read the rest of the MNRF release here:

"Helicopter bucketing helped suppress isolated pockets of higher intensity, including torching, within the perimeter of the fire.

The west side of the fire remained quiet. Crews started to work into the interior of the perimeter along the south end of Key Harbour.

Tomorrow's weather calls for higher temperatures with low humidity. The hot, dry weather, coupled with the forecasted southwesterly winds, may cause an increase in fire behaviour and test our fire lines. If such an event occurs, we have the resources to respond appropriately.

It is important to note that while good progress is being made, the fire remains active. The conditions continue to be very dry, and extreme burning conditions are still possible. Land and water restrictions remain in place at this time for protection of people, property and to allow our crews to do their work. Patrols from OPP and Conservation Officers will continue throughout the area around the fire.

We continue to work hard to manage Parry Sound 33 in order to get people back into their residences safely. We thank you for your patience and ongoing support.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Thursday, August 2, 11:40 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown to 11,185 hectares in size, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

The ministry reports that Thursday, August 2, was another great day for crews working and laying hose around the perimeter of the fire. Crews continue to make excellent progress in critical areas, especially along the northeast side of the fire near the Pickerel River. Higher winds out of the southwest today tested the northeast perimeter, but the hose lines held and kept the fire's spread in check. It is estimated that most of the east flank has been tied with hose line.

On Thursday, August 2, waterbombers and helicopters worked in conjunction with the crews to help tie off areas of activity. The fire remains south of Key Harbour, and north of the Henvey Inlet waterway. Crews are working on perimeter containment on the southeast side of the fire north of Henvey Inlet.

The west side of the fire remains unchanged; the fire remained quiet in the vicinity of Fox Island on the western perimeter. Crews continue suppression along the western flank of the fire. Structural protection continues.

Even with Thursday's winds, the fire remains approximately five kilometers away from Highway 69 and less than one kilometer south of the Pickerel River near the CN trestle bridge on the west side of Highway 69. Today's weather calls for another day of southwesterly winds.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Wednesday, August 1, 11:55 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown to 11,039 hectares in size, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

The ministry reports recent weather allowed more accurate aerial mapping of the fire and aerial ignition in the southeast added to the increased size. Fire behaviour was less active yesterday, August 1, as high humidity levels and cloud cover aided in fire suppression. Winds were generally out of the east today and changed the fire's direction of spread to the west. Hose lines on the west side of the fire held the fire's spread in check.

The ministry reports that excellent progress was made on the eastern side of the fire as crews were able to establish lines due to reduced fire behaviour when compared to previous days. Crews are laying hose from the Pickerel River south to establish a perimeter on areas that have passed over the CN line. Structural protection continues along the Key and French Rivers.

Crews continue to work the perimeter of the fire by the north and northwest of Key Harbour. Sixty firefighters remain along the east side, south of the Key River to continue perimeter containment. Aerial ignition occurred in the southeast part of the fire removing hazardous fuels and tying the fire into the northern shore of Henvey Inlet.

Even though the focus of aerial fire suppression is on the northeast side, crews continue to supress and monitor all portions of the fire. The fire remained quiet in the vicinity of Fox Island on the western perimeter. North and east winds yesterday, August 1, made for smoky conditions in communities to the south. Winds are forecasted to be out of the south today, August 2, moving to the southwest in the afternoon. The fire is approximately five kilometres west of highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of Pickerel River near the CN trestle bridge on the west side of highway 69.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Tuesday, July 31, 10:45 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown to 10,139 hectares in size, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry.

On Tuesday, July 31, fire behaviour was less active as humidity levels and cloud cover aided in fire suppression. The northeast portion of the fire closest to the Pickerel River was the most active part today. Winds from the southwest pushed some activity along the Pickerel, but it's still holding south of the river. The northeast corner of the fire is tucked along the west side of Little Canoe Channel. Ignition operations in that area were completed Tuesday evening, July 31, to tie the fire together and slow its progression down.

Structural protection continues. Additional protection occurred along the Key and French Rivers with sprinklers set up in noted priority zones. Crews worked the perimeter of the fire by continuing hose line north and northwest of Key Harbour. Sixty firefighters were placed along the east side, south of the Key River to continue perimeter containment. Even though the focus is on the northeast side, the ministry continues to supress and monitor all portions of the fire.

Winds are forecasted to be out of the north today, Aug, 1. The fire is approximately five kilometres west of Highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of Pickerel River.

The Municipality of Killarney issued an evacuation order for residents in the areas of Travers, Allen, Struthers, Kilpatrick, Bigwood (including Hartley Bay Road), a portion of Mowat, the Unsurveyed Area, 14 Mile Island and French River Provincial Park. For information, call the municipality at 705-287-2424.

PARRY SOUND -- UPDATE (Monday, July 30, 11:52 p.m.): The Parry Sound 33 forest fire reportedly expanded by 749 hectares on Monday, reaching 8,973 hectares, according to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services. The fire is now approximately five kilometres west of Highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of the Pickerel River.

On Monday, July 30, winds occurred from the west/southwest. The northeast and east portions of the fire were the most active and a few of these sections progressed eastward towards the CN Line. Crews have been working hard to slow the fire's progression in this part of the fire.

Structural protection continues, with sprinklers set up on structures along the Pickerel and Key Rivers, as well as on structures along the French River on Hartley Bay Road.

Crews worked on the southeast portion to hold the perimeter and complete hose line, while water bucketing and water bombers along the east flank continued aerial suppression efforts to attempt to close in the fire.

The ministry reported that although the focus is currently on the northeast side, they continue to suppress and monitor all portions of the fire. Aerial ignition on portions of the fire near Fox Island have brought the fire to natural boundaries removing the fire hazard in this area.

The fire behaviour today, Tuesday, July 31, is expected to remain the same as Monday. High temperatures mixed with low humidity will be present on the fire site. Winds from the west/southwest will occur again into today, possibly bringing more smoke into surrounding communities and along Highway 69.

An Evacuation Alert has been issued by the Municipality of French River for the Alban area, west of the high-powered hydro lines on Highway 64. For more information on the evacuation, call the municipality at 705-898-2294 or visit frenchriver.ca.

- OPP North East (@OPP_NER) July 31, 2018

By the evening of July 30 there were 41 active forest fires across northeast Ontario. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 26 are either being held, under control or being observed.

Remember #ParrySound33 is an active fire. For your safety, please avoid the fire area and help us fight this fire. #Waterbombers can't drop if you are in the way. Stay safe! #Ontario #forestfires pic.twitter.com/dCWWuyZhjC

- ONForestFires (@ONforestfires) July 30, 2018

UPDATE (Sunday, July 29, 11:45 p.m.): The ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports Parry Sound 33 forest fire has grown again, to 8,224 hectares.

Smoke may be visible in areas north and northeast of the fire due to winds from the south which may impact visibility along Highway 69 and local communities.

#ParrySound 33 is now listed at 8,224 ha. #Smoke drift may be visible in the areas north and northeast of the fire due to winds from the south, which could impact Hwy 69/400 and local communities. Please call 511 for HWY closure information. #forestfires #ontario pic.twitter.com/pZ7WpivbJT

- ONForestFires (@ONforestfires) July 29, 2018

The ministry reports northern areas of the fire held up well Sunday, July 29, west of Key Junction; however, parts of the northeast flanks south of Key Junction were quite active, but haven't yet crossed the rail line.

Structural protection was completed in Henvey Inlet. Protection for Key River and Grundy Lake will begin today. Equipment will be removed from Key Harbour as perimeter control has been completed in that area.

Aerial suppression continued yesterday with water bomber and water bucketing efforts on the east flank of the fire. Winds from the west and southwest are expected to continue today, Monday, July 30, possibly bringing more smoke into surrounding communities and along Highway 69. The fire remains six kilometres west of Highway 69 and less than one kilometre south of the Pickerel River near the CN trestle bridge on the west side of Highway 69.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE (8:26 a.m. Sunday, July 29) - Parry Sound 33 had minimal growth yesterday increasing in size from 7,297 to 7,651.

In a news release sent out by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry shortly before midnight on Saturday, July 28, the fire is still listed as not under control.

Water bombers and helicopters worked most of the day on July 28, limiting movement among most areas of the fire's perimeter with generally good results.

The southwest winds are expected to continue today, possibly bringing heavy smoke conditions periodically into surrounding communities along Highway 69. The fire remains approximately seven kilometres west of Highway 69 and three kilometres south of the Pickerel River and is nearly 100 kilometres north of Parry Sound.

For most of Saturday, July 28, winds from the southwest continued, keeping the northeast side as the most active part of the fire. Priority remains along the northeast side of the fire with fingers extending toward the CN rail line as minimal movement occurred across the tracks. Additionally, there was minimal growth along the southwest portion of the fire.

Hose lay and containment will continue along the northern portion as crews look to secure that area.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (8:20 a.m. Saturday, July 28) - Parry Sound 33 is still not under control and continues to grow.

In a news release sent out at 12:35 a.m. on July 28, the fire has grown to 7,297 hectares. Due to the southwest winds, the northeast side is the most active part of the fire.

The northeast side of the fire is the focus for Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry water bombers and helicopter bucketing, as it is closest to the rail line and more populated areas.

There has been minimal growth on the southwest end of the fire.

Southwest winds are expected to continue tomorrow, possibly bringing heavy smoke conditions periodically into surrounding commentates and along Highway 69. The fire is approximately seven kilometres west of Highway 69 and three kilometres south of the Pickerel River.

Wildfire crews continue to make progress around the southwest side of the perimeter by laying hose lines and actively attacking hot spots in the Key Harbour. That area is protected and the MNRF does not expect any movement in that area over the next few days.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 p.m. Thursday, July 26): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry reports Parry Sound 33 is still not under control and growing.

According to the ministry in a news release dated 11:55 p.m., Thursday, July 26, by the evening of July 26 there were 45 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 15 are not yet under control, 30 are either being held, under control or being observed. Of the 15 not under control, Parry Sound 33 is one of them.

As of July 26, the fire is estimated at 6,760 hectares and there was minimal grown on the north, west and south end of the fire. The implementation order and all access restriction, including water access restriction, remain in place. The southwest winds are expected to continue today, possibly gusting from 30 to 40 kilometres per hour. Unfortunately, there is minimal precipitation in the forecast.

"Crews continue to make excellent progress around the southwest side of the perimeter, laying hose and working on hotspots north and south of Key River," reads the release."Today's focus was on the north and east flank of the fire, which were once again active due to sustained southern and southwesterly winds. The fire did put on some growth along the east flank, with one area of the fire crossing both Tower Lake and impacting the CN rail in one location."

Continued growth of the fire is expected on the northeast flank today. Water bombers and helicopters worked most of the day halting or slowing the spread of the fire. Values protection, or sprinklers, continue to be placed along Pickerel River and began in Henvey Inlet as a precautionary measure.

PARRY SOUND - UPDATE: (11:55 a.m. Wednesday, July 25): The Ministry of Natural Resources and Fire has expanded Northeast region restricted fire zone.

Due to strong, warmer and drier lake effect winds the ministry required aerial fire suppression yesterday, July 25, as fire activity increased. As a result of the the southwest winds, smoke was pushed across Highway 69 and into some communities to the east of the fire.

Resources yesterday included CL415 water bombers, two bird dog aircraft, heavy helicopters T802 amphibious aircraft and ground crews, the ministry reports.

Additional crews from Mexico arrived on the fire today, bringing the total number of firefighters helping to suppress the fire to 90. Values protection, or sprinklers, will continue to be put in place on structures along the Pickerel River today.

"Given the unpredictability of the fire, all access restrictions, including water restrictions, remain in place for the foreseeable future," reads a ministry press release. "In the interest of public safety, on July 21, 2018 the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry (MNRF)'s Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area below impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only: All areas ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay."

There is also a recommendation by the ministry Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

By the evening of July 25 there were 50 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 16 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There were two new fires confirmed in the region today. Hearst 14, located approximately 42 kilometres south of Hearst, is two hectares and not yet under control. Two crews provided initial attack on the fire with aerial suppression support. Wawa 11 is being held at 0.1 hectares 75 kilometres southeast of Longlac.

(Tuesday, July 24, 11:10 p.m.):The fire is expected to remain relatively quiet for the next couple of days.

"However, fire conditions and behaviour can change quickly. Crews continue to monitor weather and fire behaviour closely. Residents will see smoke in the area as crews continue suppression efforts. Values protection have been put in place in Key Harbour, along parts of the south side of Pickerel River and along a portion of the train tracks east of the fire."

A total of eight helicopters worked the fire on July 24.

As of July 24 the fire was at 5,612 hectares and still not under control.

The cause of the fire was originally stated as "human" on the MNR's website but that classification has since been removed, McCool said, to avoid public speculation.

"Because the cause is still unknown at this time and it is under investigation."

(11:59 p.m., Monday, July 23): The Key River forest fire, known as Parry Sound 33, is now covering an area of 5,612 hectares and the restricted fire zone has been expanded to north of Rosseau.

According to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services, Parry Sound 33 saw aerial fire suppression again on Monday, July 23. CL415s dropped water on the fire which was remapped at 5,612 hectares. Three heavy helicopters bucketed water to reduce the fire's intensity and co-ordinated with ground crews.

On July 21, the MNRF's Parry Sound district recommended that the communities, municipalities and townships within the area ranging from the western and northern borders of French River Provincial Park, east to Highway 69, and as far south as the south shore of the Key River; including all residents and members of the public on both the north and south shores of the French River, and the Pickerel River, as well as Hartley Bay impose a mandatory evacuation of their residents with boat access only.

There is also a recommendation by the MNRF Parry Sound district to impose an evacuation alert to all residents within this area who have road access to their residences or cottages. These residents should be prepared to evacuate pending a change in the fire situation.

In addition, the MNRF's Sudbury district has recommended that all residents along Hartley Bay Road be placed on an evacuation alert, pending changes to the fire situation.

The Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) and Conservation Officers have been on site helping notify the public of the situation, and facilitating this evacuation.

Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services (AFFES) has also been advised by Ontario Parks that the French River Provincial Park is fully closed west of Highway 69/400. All campers have been or are being evacuated. Ontario Parks has also suspended permit sales for the French River Delta and Pickerel River areas and are restricting entry to park users (everything west of Highway 69/400).

Henvey Inlet First Nation declared a state of emergency as a precautionary measure. As of July 22, the community has successfully and safely evacuated all of its community members, who are receiving accommodation and food.

By the evening of July 23 there were 55 active forest fires across the northeast. Of these, 21 are not yet under control, 34 are either being held, under control or being observed.

There was only one new start in the region today. Sudbury 92 located near Johnnie Lake in Killarney Provincial Park covers 0.1 of a hectare and is already under control.

urn:contentItem:4NRB-RC00-TX4V-K2XX-00000-00One forest fire in northwestern Ontario is in hand; second expected to grow2007-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:46ZLexisNexisGENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWSOne forest fire in northwestern Ontario is in hand; second expected to growCP

THUNDER BAY, Ont. (CP) _ Choking smoke above a large forest fire in northwestern Ontario grounded water bombers after winds died down and the smoke settled, making visibility difficult, officials said Monday.

The fire, known as Thunder Bay 37, was expected to reach 10,000 hectares in size.

A group of 130 firefighters from British Columbia arrived in Thunder Bay, Ont., Sunday night to help battle the flames along with a number of other fires in the region.

As of Sunday, the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources reported 13 active fires in the region, including Thunder Bay 37, the fire that jumped the border from Minnesota into Ontario last week.

Bob Thomas, a spokesman with Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources, said most of the newcomers would be deployed to the big fire.

A single millimetre of rain fell Sunday night.

''It's a start,'' Thomas said on Monday.

''There is a chance of more rain in the forecast for today and into tonight, but it could be a mixed blessing in the sense that there could be some lightning thrown in with it.''

As many as 300 people, mostly cottagers, have been evacuated from the fire's path while a few hundred more are on alert.

Thanks to cooler temperatures and dying winds, a second fire, this one just 50 kilometres north of Thunder Bay, has responded to attempts to knock it down.

The fire grew rapidly Sunday and by late afternoon, covered 1,000 hectares.

Thomas called it a ''contentious'' fire.

''It is also in a very heavy recreation use area,'' he said.

Officials were concerned they would have to close down the Armstrong Highway, which runs from Lake Superior to the community of Armstrong on the west side of Lake Nipigon, but that wasn't needed.

Only eight cottagers had to be evacuated and it was expected they would be allowed to go back Monday.

Thomas said fire crews appeared to have a handle on that fire.

''Our batting average so far this spring hasn't been great, so it's nice to get one,'' he said.

(CP) - Firefighting crews continued to battle a stubborn forest fire near this small logging town as hot weather persisted, raising temperatures to nearly 30 C on Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Most of the flames were extinguished Wednesday but a smouldering forest floor has kept officials busy patrolling hotspots that flared up several times Friday.</p><p>-BODY- "The weather is against us,'' said town councillor Bill Mayne. "It's a tinderbox around here. (The forest) could ignite anywhere, anytime, and that's the situation.''</p><p>Crews and water bombers managed to put out Friday's flames, some as near as eight kilometres from this central Newfoundland town of 1,000 people.</p><p>Gerald Fleming, provincial forest fire duty officer, said the fire is still listed as out of control and has claimed approximately 6,600 hectares of forest.</p><p>He said a crew of 210 firefighters, four water bombers and four helicopters were working on the fire.</p><p>The province banned recreational use at three area lakes until further notice. Water bombers have been using water from the lakes to fight the fire.</p><p>Ivan Downton, forestry service duty officer, said the fire is not a threat to the town but also said it continues to grow.</p><p>He said the fire grew by 10 to 15 per cent on Thursday.</p><p>No injuries have been reported, but the fire did destroy three cabins since starting Saturday as a result of a lightening strike.</p><p>Residents of Badger were ordered to leave the town Monday as flames came within 250 metres of western outskirts.</p><p>They were allowed to return Wednesday when officials believed they had contained the fire, then located within a kilometre from the town.</p><p>Forestry officials said Friday they were concerned about southerly winds expected on the weekend.</p><p>Winds gusting at 40 to 60 kilometres per hour, which could fan the fire, are expected throughout Saturday.</p><p>"That's just what we don't want,'' said town councillor Pearl Noel.</p><p>Temperatures are expected to be in the mid-20s. (Corner Brook Western Star-St. John's Telegram)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5PK3-JN61-JDH3-G18T-00000-00District going after wildfire mitigation grant2017-09-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:46ZLexisNexisNEWSDistrict going after wildfire mitigation grantBarry Gerding

The District of Lake Country is seeking a grant to develop a wildfire protection plan for the community.

Council has voted to submit an application to the UBCM-Strategic Wildfire Prevention Initiative, which would cover 75 per cent of the plan study, to a maximum of $22,500.

The remaining 25 per cent of the cost would be covered by the district.

The CWPP program assists local governments and First Nations in identifying the risks of wildfire to their community and how those risks could be reduced.

The Night Hawk wildfire was a lesson on how quickly fires can spread, and how forest fire fuels on the ground can intensify it.

Coun. Penny Gambell said a tree retention policy she is advocating for would initially seem to fly in the face of any forest fire mitigation efforts.

But she noted both elements would help to further address the wildfire mitigation risks for Lake Country in the future.

She suggested tree spacing as one example of a tree retention policy that also impacts how wildfires can candle or jump ahead quickly and spread, or lessen the potential overall intensity of a fire.

The grant would allow for a professional forester to carry out a baseline impact assessment which would form the basis for creating a district wildfire prevention plan.

B1 / FRONT</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo><nitf:fixture xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/">News</nitf:fixture></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest fire threat worsens : Eight northern towns warned: be ready to run</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Nelson Wyatt</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The forest fire scenario in northeastern Ontario went from bad to worse yesterday with the expansion of an evacuation alert.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A 48-hour evacuation stand-by notice already in effect in an area west of Kirkland Lake was expanded to other parts of the province.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The situation in the forest is extreme," said Wayne LeBelle, a spokesman for the Ministry of Natural Resources.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Canadian Press</p></bodyText></section><p>"The winds are there, there's only supposed to be a little amount of rain. It's tinder dry, so it's not a good situation."</p><p>Lebelle said threatened areas included Chapleau, Gogama, Kirkland Lake, New Liskeard, Timmins, Cochrane, Kapuskasing and Hearst.</p><p>He said it wasn't a "panic situation" and that the evacuation alert was extended as a planning measure to let people know they could be asked to leave.</p><p>The Ontario fires cast a smoky pall over the region as well as Quebec and parts of Eastern Canada.</p><p>The largest Ontario blaze was a 5,000-hectare fire burning just to the west of Kirkland Lake.</p><p>That fire forced the evacuation of more than 100 cottages in the Watabeag Lake area and threatened two other nearby communties on Highway 11.</p><p>Health officials warned heavy smoke could cause problems for people hundreds of kilometres away.</p><p>Steve Deegan, a Temiskaming district health inspector, advised the region's elderly and people with cardiovascular and respiratory problems to stay indoors.</p><p>Smoke also made driving hazardous. Visibility was significantly reduced on stretches of highway near Kirkland Lake.</p><p>The mayor of Latchford, near Temagami, said he hasn't seen smoke like this since the 1950s.</p><p>But in Quebec, the situation had stabilized even though heavy smoke from more than 100 fires prevented 1,600 evacuees from returning home.</p><p>The trouble spots in Quebec included timber and mining regions in the northwest and spots along the north and south shores of the St. Lawrence River.</p><p>In the Maritimes, the haze of smoke that wafted in from Quebec a day earlier was far less noticeable yesterday.</p><p>But the forest fire index in most of the Maritimes remained high, with parts of New Brunswick in the extreme risk urn:contentItem:5CWD-JVP1-DY91-K0M7-00000-00Forest fire evacuees could go home soon2011-07-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:46ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A6Forest fire evacuees could go home soonThe Canadian Press

People evacuated from northwestern Ontario communities because of forest fires could begin returning home soon, provincial government officials said Sunday.

The government is working on a plan to allow those affected by the fires to go back to their communities, said Ian Davidson, deputy minister of Community Safety.

"That will be based on personal safety and developing a plan with individual First Nations, but we're working on that right now," Davidson said.

He did not give a timetable for the return but said "it could happen relatively quickly."

Asked about the situation, Premier Dalton McGuinty said "the fire does appear at this point in time to be less threatening than in past days."

"We're working now to take care of families that have been displaced, and when it's safe to do so we'll help them get back home," he said.

Almost 3,600 people have been removed from communities since evacuations began June 21. Many of them have been moved to regional centres such as London and Thunder Bay.

Three First Nations communities have been fully evacuated while another six have been partially evacuated. Officials from those communities could not be reached for comment Sunday.

Davidson said there are no further evacuations planned at this time.

Government officials will decide who will get to return home first based on the safety of their destinations and the capacity of the government to move them, he said.

There were 10 new fires as of 6 p.m. Saturday, said Norma Griffin, the spokeswoman for the provincial Ministry of Natural Resources. That brings the total number of active fires to 118. More were expected to be added Sunday.

The forest fires in northwestern Ontario, such as this one near Red Lake, have become "less threatening." THE CANADIAN PRESS

(CP) - As a menacing cloud of black smoke towered in the distance, residents of this western Manitoba town hosed down their houses yesterday in a last-ditch defence against a massive, unpredictable forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A change in wind direction helped push the Cowan blaze away from town, after it had consumed more than 40,000 hectares (98,800 acres) of timber, brush and buildings, but residents were taking no chances.</p><p>"This fire just seems to wander wherever it wants to, depending on the wind and the fuel conditions," said officer Rick Tease at the firefighting base camp.</p><p>"If the wind picks up and changes direction and the fire escapes the lines it's contained in now, the town could be in danger again."</p><p>Tease said the blaze, which started Thursday morning, is unusual in that it "crowns" at night. That means it rolls forward, burning the tops of trees first, then scorches across the ground.</p><p>Arson feared</p><p>Usually sunset gives firefighters a breather but it's too dry and too hot in Manitoba right now, where more than 100 fires continue to burn.</p><p>Authorities believe the fire was set deliberately and are investigating.</p><p>The heavily forested area around Cowan was declared a disaster area Sunday, when the fire jumped a main highway and roared within a couple of kilometres of the town. In it's path was Briggs Spur, where a church and a house were levelled but the remaining eight houses were left unscathed.</p><p>The RCMP ordered everyone out of Briggs Spur and Cowan, communities of cottage-like homes 400 kilometres (249 miles) northwest of Winnipeg.</p><p>Almost 2,000 firefighters are battling the blazes in Manitoba with help from 11 waterbombers and 36 helicopters. So far this year, forest fires have consumed an area equal in size to Prince Edward Island and have forced about 1,300 people from their homes.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source (CP) - Hot, dry weather is expected for the next three days in Ontario's northwest where firefighters are battling to control a forest fire.</p><p>"There is no rain in the forecast until at least Wednesday but we're hoping for some relief," said Mitch Miller, a spokesman for the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources' fire centre in Dryden.</p><p>About 300 ministry firefighters are battling the 250-square-kilometre blaze west of Lake Nipigon that was reported April 30.</p><p>"The fire hazard is continuing. I won't say it hampers our efforts but Mother Nature is not helping our crews out there very much,'' said Miller.</p><p>On Saturday, crews burned areas of forest in the path of the fire in an effort to control its spread, said Dave Jackson, a spokesman with the ministry's fire centre in Thunder Bay.</p><p>"There's a fair amount of fire under the trees . . so we burned off the area in three large blocks," Jackson said.</p><p>During the next few days crews will attempting to surround the fire by linking hose lines with bulldozed areas. The fire will then be fought to its centre, said Miller.</p><p>The ministry has extended a restricted fire ban in the northwest, taking in the area between the Manitoba border and the west side of Lake Nipigon. (Thunder Bay Chronicle Journal)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5WJC-M5V1-JBTY-W0GG-00000-00Wildfire threatening First Nation grows2019-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:46ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A6Wildfire threatening First Nation growsFire near Pikangikum now larger than size of Quebec CityEmerald Bensadoun The Canadian Press

A forest fire threatening a First Nation in northwestern Ontario has grown in size, officials said Thursday as more flights were planned to airlift residents out of the community.

Members of Pikangikum First Nation have been leaving their homes since a full evacuation was ordered on Monday, although departures via buses and boats were put on hold Wednesday because of a lack of places to send evacuees. Saskatchewan has since said it would take in up to 2,000 displaced residents.

The Ministry of Natural Resources said the fire - dubbed Red Lake Fire 39 - has now grown to more than 507 square kilometres in size, which is larger than Quebec City.

The blaze was burning six kilometres southwest of Pikangikum, on the opposite side of a lake. Crews were setting up hose lines on the east and northwest sides of the fire, and sprinklers have been installed southwest of the community, the ministry said.

Spokesperson Jolanta Kowalski said there are 84 firefighters now working on the fire, but that number was expected to rise. "With large fires like Red Lake 39, even a small amount of growth along the perimeter will have a significant impact on size," she said.

The Canadian Armed Forces said as of Thursday morning, around 1,350 of Pikangikum's 3,800 residents had been airlifted out of the community, with more flights scheduled for later in the day.

Evacuations by land and water routes remained on hold, said Mathew Hoppe, commander of Pikangikum's emergency operations centre in Thunder Bay, explaining that there were still "logistical issues" to sort out.

"There's still challenges as far as I know, about host community access when we put people on buses," he said. "We want to minimize having people sit on buses for 10 or 12 hours."

Alvin Fiddler, grand chief of the Nishnawbe Aski Nation - which represents 49 First Nations across Northern Ontario - said Saskatchewan's offer to host evacuees was nonetheless a "relief."

"There's been so much pressure on the leadership of Pikangikum, on some of the front-line workers who have been at this for many days now, to be able to tell the evacuees where they're going to be going," Fiddler said Thursday.

"It alleviates a lot of the pressure that centres in the northwest part of the province have been feeling with the request to accommodate more evacuees."

Meanwhile, Red Lake Fire 23, a forest fire raging eight kilometres south of the community of Keewaywin, has grown to 926 square kilometres - nearly twice the size of the fire threatening Pikangikum.

Keewaywin First Nation completed a full evacuation of its roughly 450 residents last week who were relocated to Sioux Lookout and Timmins.

(CP) _ Saskatchewan's first major forest fire of the year was being held Tuesday, but not before it burned its way into this tiny northern community.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>A heavy rain Monday night helped crews get the upper hand on the massive blaze, said John Cook of the provincial fire control centre in Prince Albert. Some outlying buildings were destroyed but no homes burned.</p><p>Residents of the tiny village were evacuated Sunday. Cook said it will be up to local officials to decide when they can return.</p><p>"We were expecting to make good progress (Monday) with winds from the southwest and a chance of thundershowers,'' he said.</p><p>"But what happened was one of those thundershowers realized a enormous amount of rain on the area. There were puddles with as much as six inches of water on the ground.''</p><p>"We do not believe that there is any significant threat to the community, at this point. But we have to emphasize that the decision to return to the community is always with the community leaders themselves.''</p><p>Steven Bobiash, of the Community Resources Department, said 44 evacuees were being put up in La Ronge, a larger town further to the north.</p><p>Cook said the fire has consumed 58 square kilometres of wilderness _ an area about half the size of Regina.</p><p>It started on the northern tip of Bittern Lake, about 200 kilometres north of Saskatoon, and moved to the north, missing the larger community of Montreal Lake but hitting Timber Bay.</p><p>So far this year, there have been 155 forest fires in Saskatchewan. That's well under the 283 fires that had burned to this point last year.</p><p>While the cause of the fire is still under investigation, Cook said it's likely due to human activity.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">CAPRSS-20030527CPCPD1109</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CAPRSS2003</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:48PJ-9T10-01G6-932B-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">253760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="279"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Canadian Press (CP)</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2003 Press News Limited, All Rights Reserved</copyright><publicationDate day="27" month="05" year="2003"><dateText>May 27, 2003 Tuesday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newswires & Press Releases</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="licensor.indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="licensor.subject"><classificationItem><className>ENVIRONMENT; urn:contentItem:4H7D-N8F0-00RJ-F46F-00000-00<published>2005-09-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><broadcastInfo><show><showName>CTV NEWS</showName></show><newsAnchors>LLOYD ROBERTSON</newsAnchors></broadcastInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Forest Fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>LLOYD ROBERTSON: Firefighters in southern California are making progress as they battle a raging wildfire that has ripped through more than 30 square kilometres of hills and canyons. Tonight, hundreds of people who were forced to leave their homes are being allowed to return. But the fire that broke out Wednesday is far from being classified as under control. One of the hot spots is Simi Valley and that's where CTV's Los Angeles bureau chief Graham Richardson is located tonight on the front lines with the firefighters.</p><p>GRAHAM RICHARDSON [Reporter]: Fires have scorched the land black all around these homes. There is some relief today. Temperatures are cooler. The winds have died. Fire crews are settling into a routine, except here. One part of this summer camp is still smouldering from last night.</p><p>GARY BRENGLASS [Camp Director]: Yesterday by eight, nine o'clock at night we thought the worst was well behind us.</p><p>RICHARDSON: They were wrong. At the other end of the property, another small brush fire kicks up. We go in with firefighters for a closer look.</p><p>CAPT. STEVE GREEN [California Department of Forestry]: This is an isolated area right now and we're comfortable with it. And you see it's not spreading sideways or anything like that because there's no wind on it right now. But you know, the situation could change.</p><p>RICHARDSON: And there were signs around us that things were about to change. And they did. We got to go?</p><p>GREEN: We got to go. Yeah, time to go.</p><p>RICHARDSON: Winds picking up?</p><p>GREEN: Yes. Coming up the canyon. That's what we don't want. So pop it in there and let's go. What concerns me most is, you know, in this area right here, the fuels are burning really well.</p><p>RICHARDSON: This is what a better day on the California fire lines looks like. Just a few minutes ago, we were back in that canyon a few small fires. Within five minutes, look what it blew up into. Bulldozers protect horses building fire breaks around them. Some just ran away from the flames. From the air, helicopters attack the fire and try to keep it from growing. But the wind has picked up and it's spreading again. Graham Richardson, CTV News, Simi Valley, California.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">CTV2005</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4H7D-N8F0-00RJ-F46F-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">211506</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-31</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="367"/><timeReceived>23:09:00 - urn:contentItem:460V-MKS0-01G6-906F-00000-00<published>2001-10-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:55:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>GENERAL AND NATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Massive forest fire consumes 30 square kilometres in southwestern Alberta</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SUNDRE, Alta. (CP) _ What began as a small and contained burn two weeks ago has unexpectedly turned into a colossal wall of fire steamrolling out of control through back country northwest of Calgary.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The forest fire had consumed 30 square kilometres by Tuesday night as firefighters worked tirelessly to harness it.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>Land and forestry workers were clearing out campers and hikers while turning others away off Forestry Trunk Road, a main entrance into the Big Horn recreational area.</p><p>Massive poles of smoke could be seen 140 kilometres away while residents on the edge of Calgary reported seeing flames twirl off in the distance in the night sky.</p><p>Lisa Block, information officer with Land and Forestry, said the blaze began Sept. 30, and was quickly brought under control.</p><p>But howling winds and tinder dry conditions transformed the blaze into a firestorm.</p><p> Due to conditions, it's jumped and escaped,'' Block said.</p><p>Only the Blue Hill Ranger Station was evacuated Tuesday night, with dozens of campers at Ya Ha Tinda Ranch and firefighters at Mountain Aire Lodge on stand-by orders to flee.</p><p> It's like a giant mushroom cloud _ I can see it from the door,'' said Lodge co-manager Rhonda Girling.</p><p>About two dozen firefighters were using Girling's Lodge as a base of operations. As many as 100 more were expected to reach the Lodge on Wednesday to help battle the blaze.</p><p>Block said the fire was heading northeast in a slow encroachment to Sundre 50 kilometres away, but waived off fears it could hit the town.</p><p> There are no plans for evacuation for Sundre, it's too far from that right now,'' she said.</p><p>Officials are calling for up to five millimetres of snow in the region, which could help boost efforts to bring it back under control.</p><p> It doesn't sound like much, but with the cooler temperatures, it will be beneficial,'' she said.</p><p>(Calgary Sun)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
