urn:contentItem:4J9M-8X80-TX77-D2Y9-00000-00Winners & losers from forest fire2001-10-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:46ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Winners & losers from forest fireJohnnie BachuskyRed Deer Express

Financial winners and losers are emerging from the smoke and ashes of Central Alberta's worst forest fire in more than 60 years.

On Wednesday, the fire was downgraded by provincial officials as ``under control'' following more than a week of devastation in a forested alpine wilderness area 40 kilometres southwest of Sundre.

Although it may take up to two years to calculate the dollar value of its timber losses from the fire, Vancouver-based Sunpine Forest Products Ltd, the foresty company directly hit along the path of the blaze, admits it has lost 7,500 hectares of timber from its Forestry Management Area, including cutblocks reforested 30 years ago.

As well, at least $3 million in tree-harvesting equipment from one of Sunpine's key contractors had to be abandoned.

``This year has been a bad one,'' said Tom Daniels, Sunpine community affairs forester. He said a further 600 hectares of timber was destroyed by an earlier but smaller fire this year.

``It will take up to two years to determine what impact this will have from a volume perspective,'' said Daniels.

Although on first glance it would appear Sunpine's losses are enormous, Daniels said not all of the destruction occurred in areas where timber was ``merchandisable.''

As well, the Vancouver-based company has a total of 500,000 hectares or 500 square kilometres of forest in its provincially-approved harvesting region, and will now turn to other areas for future harvesting.

``It not that we have lost this land,'' said Daniels. ``It's still there but we have to determine what we can salvage.''

Not every industry in the region has been dealt a financial knock-out blow.

Since Oct. 17, the Mountain Aire Lodge, a camp facility and 12-unit motel located at the junction of the Red Deer River and the Forestry Truck Road, has been accommodating up to 200 provincial fire fighting personnel.

Owner Ross Legge, a former Calgary electrician who bought the 41-year-old lodge last February, said he won't release specific details of his agreement with the province but said he is receiving ``considerable more than $40 a day'' for food and accommodation from each guest.

``It's going to help me see through the winter,'' said Legge. ``We're proving to the industry people in the area that we can accommodate then in the future if problems like this arise.''

He said he expects a good number of the firefighting crew to stay until at least the first week of November.

The fire was ignited late September from an abandoned camp fire and grew out-of-control by Oct. 16. By this week, the blaze eventually swept through 11,130 hectares of prime timber country.

Fire crews have been busy digging an 86-km fire break around the blaze. As of Wednesday, firefighters said they have 75 per cent of the fire contained.

However, progress has been slow and difficult because they have been working around snow and ice in challenging mountainous terrain.

The road to Ya Ha Tinda Ranch and the Forestry Truck Road (Secondary Highway 734) are now open but only under controlled access.

urn:contentItem:5WGW-WH21-JDH1-C4NG-00000-00First Nation community evacuated due to fire2019-07-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:55:46ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. B1First Nation community evacuated due to fireColin Perkel The Canadian PressThe Canadian Press

A raging forest fire in northwestern Ontario has prompted the full evacuation of the First Nation community of Keewaywin, authorities said on Thursday.

More than 200 residents considered vulnerable had already been flown this week to Sioux Lookout, Ont., as the fire moved closer, while roughly 200 more were being sent to another city Thursday.

Joe Meekis, a former longtime chief of Keewaywin - which has about 450 residents - called the situation scary.

"The community is threatened," Meekis said in an interview from Sioux Lookout. "Everybody has to get out."

Known as Red Lake Fire Number 23, the blaze is now about 546 square kilometres. It began as a small fire a week ago about 40 kilometres from the community. Earlier this week, the winds picked up and it "grew really fast," Meekis said.

Smoke began drifting into the community, prompting residents to close windows and doors, and shut down air conditioners.

Ultimately, the chief declared an emergency, and the initial transfer of babies, pregnant women and children under five and their families began. On Tuesday and Wednesday, a total of 227 people were flown about 330 kilometres south to Sioux Lookout, which has declared its own state of emergency aimed at defraying the cost of helping the arrivals.

Volunteers in the town were helping provide access to snacks, supplies and information, as well as responding to requests from the evacuees, a spokesperson said.

"All evacuees are being housed at a local hotel, and a local restaurant is providing all of the meals," said Brian MacKinnon, the town's manager of corporate services. "(However), Sioux Lookout is presently at capacity with respect to the number of evacuees we can host."

As a result, the remaining evacuees, numbering more than 200, were being flown to Timmins, Ont., on Thursday, leaving just a skeleton crew in the community for security purposes, Meekis said.

"They're moving people today, as we speak," Meekis said.

By noon Thursday, the fire was 10 kilometres southwest of the Keewaywin boundary, which is 12 kilometres from the town itself, according to the provincial Ministry of Natural Resources.

Jonathan Scott, an information officer with Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services, said an incident management team was on site looking for "aerial ignition opportunities" in which fires are deliberately set to take the blaze to natural barriers and slow its spread. Crews and equipment were also in the area.

In all, more than two dozen fires are burning in northwestern Ontario, 12 out of control.

Large numbers of huge forest fires are not unusual in the region. There have been 183 to date this season, well below the 500 of last year and about half the 10-year average of 366, Scott said.
